reviewText: The Witness is really quite unique. The main draw of this game in the beginning is its beautifully crafted environment, which is pretty much completely explorable and packed with detail. The only gameplay element aside from simple movement is in mouse-based interaction with line puzzles (controller works too, but I found I wanted more precision). Basically these are those puzzles that require you to trace a shape without crossing the same spot more than once. The rules are never spelled out, but the game is great at encouraging the player to learn through experimentation and exploration. I hesitate to say any more about it, because some of the most awesome moments in this game are in figuring out what's going on.\n\nThe secrets are the fun part of the game, which is why it's so frustrating that a few of the secrets are so damn obscure. After a certain point, I was aware that there was more to do, based on a few glimpses of locked-off areas, but I had exhausted almost everything else of interest. I really wanted to find everything worthwhile in this game without spoilers, but the game turned into hours of me squinting at the screen for some hint about what to do next. I even tried solving a nearly accessible puzzle through the cracks in a plank ceiling to make progress (which, let's be honest, would've been an epic solution if it worked). Honestly, trying to solve that mystery on my own turned into a pretty low point in the game. For any but the most determined, if you are to that point, I actually recommend getting a hint or two. But first, try to explore and experiment for as long as you find it enjoyable!

reviewText:
I like first person puzzle games. Portal, Portal 2 and The Talos Principle were all great games, while Qube and The Ball were pretty good. The Witness, however, is a mixed bag. I'd have preferred to give it a neutral rating, but on balance my feelings are more negative than positive, hence the thumbs down.

Anyway, you're a guy, or maybe a girl, I don't know, who is stuck on an island for some unknown reason, and you've got to solve some puzzles in order to do ... something. There is no story whatsoever, no explanation for who you are, or what you're trying to achieve. And without going into spoilers, the ending is a total anti-climax. Well, okay, as long as the puzzles are fun, that's the most important thing, right?

The first several hours of my time in The Witness were extremely frustrating, because compared to those other games that I mentioned above, The Witness does a terrible job of explaining its mechanics and concepts to the player. I'm not complaining about difficulty. I don't mind being stuck on a puzzle for a while, as long as I've got an idea of what I'm supposed to be doing. There's a difference between understanding the rules of a puzzle, and actually finding the solution. The best puzzles are easy to understand, but challenging to solve.

In Portal 2, the first time I stepped on the orange gel and ran face first into a wall, I immediately understood this stuff makes me run fast". In The Talos Principle

reviewText:
The game world is beautiful but sadly that's all the game has going for it. There is essentially no story to speak of. You appear and are free to do whatever. There is no obvious reason to do anything beyond unlock the first door so you can get out of the spawn location. Maybe if I invested  more time, there would be story but I doubt it.

The lack of story isn't really what killed this game for me, its the lack of puzzles. For me, to solve a puzzle, one must figure out a solution. In this game to solve a puzzle one must solve a graph optimization problem. It is a purely computational effort with no creativity involved. All puzzles are variation on labyrinth solving, but since that is very simple, some constraints are added. For example, your solution path must outline a certain shape or separate light and dark areas of the board etc. Once you figure out the constants, the process of actually solving the puzzle becomes a tedious process of trying different permutations until you arrive at the right one... Or look up the solution online.

To add insult to injury the mechanics are by no means obvious so any area that introduces a new mechanic also has an extensive tutorial system where you 'solve' progressively more difficult puzzles to get a handle on the rules of this specific  rule set. On the other hand, sprinkled thought the world are puzzles that assume advanced knowledge of mechanics that you have not yet found the tutorial for making solving them all but impossible. As a result, the game removes pretty much all elements of creative thinking from this 'puzzle' game. You either know the mechanic and the puzzle is little more than an equation that needs to be solved, or you don't know the mechanic and you have almost no hope of solving the puzzle at all.

reviewText:
The Witness is a puzzle game and it is almost exclusively so. You will not find a story to speak of beyond the barest conceit. You will not find much music or action or RPG elements. There is nothing much to pull you through the game except the rather stunning scenery and your own sense of discovery. What you will find is a very compelling concept, stretched and explored in almost every conceivable way. It does not appear that way at first though. If you have do not have a little faith in the designer (by playing Braid for example), then you may be quick to dismiss it. It seems too simple. Too easy. But it builds upon itself over and over, folding inward and outward.

By the end you will be swearing at Jonathan Blow. But again, that journey relies on you as a player. The game gives you everything you need, but never explicitly. You have to want to understand the underlying systems. Very often you will come across something unintelligible. Something you can’t solve yet because you don’t have the mental tools. You have to make note of it and come back later. I highly recommend taking notes. Pen and paper will be your best companions on this odd little island.

This is a game that will change the way you look at the world and don’t mean that in some high-minded philosophical way, but in a very specific, rather funny way. That is something I don’t think I can say about any other game. For that alone, I think The Witness is worth playing.

reviewText:
I give this game a thumbs up, but reluctantly so.  I think the idea behind the game is great and I would like to see more of the same.  90% of the puzzles were fantastic logic puzzles that challenges one sense of logic and critical thinking.  The artwork was also nice.

The problem is that abpout 10% of the puzzles were just stupid.  They weren't logical, or critical thinking puzzles, they were stand in the right spot puzzles.  The reflection puzzles were fine as you could use logic to figure out where to stand, but some of the other puzzles were just random.  I was only able to solve those by pure permutation and looking up the answer online.  And those puzzles weren't even challenging.  If you know which arbitrary view is the right one, then you already have the answer, no thinking required.  You just have to view the puzzle from every angle and distance until something lines up.

I want to get the answer by rational thought and logical pattern recognition, not by knowing where to arbitrarily stand.

The other problem is that this game makes some of the puzzles hard by just assaulting your senses.  If you are color blind or, like me ,have bad hearing, then you are just screwed.  The puzzles would be simple if you could understand what you are seeing/hearing, but the game goes out of it's way to make it hard to view/hear the puzzles.  And I can only assume the puzzles at end game are designed to induce seizures and discriminate against the epeleptic.

The sad part is that these crappy puzzles of arbitrary standing and sensory assaulting don't add anything to the game or make the challenge more rewarding.  It just makes it annoying, frustrating, painful, and forces one to look up the answer in order to finish.  I don't want to have to cheat to finish the game.

To the author: You have a great game here.  It is fun, rewarding, enjoyable, and worth playing.  Just get your next game play tested by people and if somebody can't handle a puzzle due to hearing/sight/seizure problems then redesign it.  Even those who don't have bad hearing will thank you for it.

reviewText:
God, I hate this game.

The puzzles are fine at first, but they soon start to wear on your intellect. This game doesn't polish your mind; it whittles it down, bit by bit, until all that's left is an urgent desire to feel again. So I took a break. When I returned, I found that I'd forgotten the rules for most of the puzzles.

But I will defeat it.

For in the moments where you can claim small victories over the enigmatic mass of agony that is The Witness, when you open that bamboo door and see the light stream into your eyes and take in the next vista, when you discover that underground cavern with a mysterious artifact you didn't know existed, when you forge a new path somewhere you didn't think possible, when the next laser shoots to the top of the mountain... Those moments make it all worth it.

God, I love this game.

reviewText:
After about 4 hours and 180 puzzles I feel like I've barely scratched the surface.  This is a really incredible puzzle game.  You're constantly learning new rules and building on the skills that the game is teaching you.  It's like the Socratic Method of games.  There is no instruction just a progressive building and combining of elements.

This is not a game with action or violence.  The only obstacles are the various line puzzles, and your only tools are your senses and your wits.  You need to constantly be observing the scenery and listening to the ambient noises for subtle clues that might help you solve the next panel.

If you enjoy puzzle games and want a relaxing way to spend a few hours then this is the game for you.  You'll get your money's worth.

reviewText:
Dear Jon,

I am writing to you about your magnum opus, The Witness, not out of love, but as an expression of my boredom with completing what may be the critical apex of your brain's functionality.  I understand that engineering a puzzle takes a great mind, but I feel as though you're efforts are simply too mundane.  Every day, the New York Times challenges me with a crossword puzzle that draws on my education and life experiences to craft a truly memorable and endearing experience.  The Witness reminded me of a stained glass paint kit I received as a Christmas gift.  It's an imitation of true, masterful art and only enables lesser minds to experience the physical climb towards impacting the world we share.  I can say, with no doubt in my mind, you are a smart man.  However, I beat all 700 puzzles in 10 hours and have an incredibly high IQ.  I implore you, with respect, to refund me the $40 I spent on your product as I do not make much in the world of academia.

Sincerely yours,

Hitler

10 days in, getting paranoid about the lack of people on the island. starting to see puzzles in the environment, i think im going crazy but ill try to solve them the next time i see one. I found a boat but its automated so i cant leave this island, what did i do to deserve being trapped here...

reviewText:
I give this game a thumbs up, but reluctantly so.  I think the idea behind the game is great and I would like to see more of the same.  90% of the puzzles were fantastic logic puzzles that challenges one sense of logic and critical thinking.  The artwork was also nice.

The problem is that abpout 10% of the puzzles were just stupid.  They weren't logical, or critical thinking puzzles, they were stand in the right spot puzzles.  The reflection puzzles were fine as you could use logic to figure out where to stand, but some of the other puzzles were just random.  I was only able to solve those by pure permutation and looking up the answer online.  And those puzzles weren't even challenging.  If you know which arbitrary view is the right one, then you already have the answer, no thinking required.  You just have to view the puzzle from every angle and distance until something lines up.

I want to get the answer by rational thought and logical pattern recognition, not by knowing where to arbitrarily stand.

The other problem is that this game makes some of the puzzles hard by just assaulting your senses.  If you are color blind or, like me ,have bad hearing, then you are just screwed.  The puzzles would be simple if you could understand what you are seeing/hearing, but the game goes out of it's way to make it hard to view/hear the puzzles.  And I can only assume the puzzles at end game are designed to induce seizures and discriminate against the epeleptic.

The sad part is that these crappy puzzles of arbitrary standing and sensory assaulting don't add anything to the game or make the challenge more rewarding.  It just makes it annoying, frustrating, painful, and forces one to look up the answer in order to finish.  I don't want to have to cheat to finish the game.

To the author: You have a great game here.  It is fun, rewarding, enjoyable, and worth playing.  Just get your next game play tested by people and if somebody can't handle a puzzle due to hearing/sight/seizure problems then redesign it.  Even those who don't have bad hearing will thank you for it.

reviewText: PLAYED ON PS4.\n\nAfter around 70 hours, I finally completed it. I absolutely love The Witness. Some people may be turned off by the line puzzles
date:
wondering the need for the world itself around them. But for many, there are reasons. Big reasons. Here the environment is the puzzle, the panel is where you put your answer. And then there are even more secrets to find. Explaining any further would spoil it.

There are also puzzles that don't use the environment, teaching you many of the rules of this game that will be used and built upon in the future. It won't tell you how to do them though, this game is as much about learning the puzzle as it is about solving the puzzle. But the answers are there. It can be a very hard game when it wants to, but it's never unfair. If you're stuck, the open world is great to look around and solve other puzzles.

reviewText: Really one of the best games I've played in ages. I'm not generally a fan of puzzle games. In fact, this game, Portal, and The Talos Principle are probably the only puzzle games I've finished. But this game just hooked me in and made me constantly want more. By taking away the constant stream of rewards that we're used to in modern games, it initially left me feeling a little cast off. I wasn't sure how I was supposed to play through a game if they weren't going to pull me through it, but once I started taking satisfaction in the completion of these truly mind-bending puzzles, I found myself absolutely enraptured. This is an experience I wish I could have again, and am so incredibly happy that the Witness turned out how Jonathan Blow wanted it to.

reviewText:
The Witness is a difficult game to review.

This game seems to generate some very polarizing opinions and a common theme I see from people who dislike the game is that it seems they didn't really know what they were getting into.  Some expected a more narrative experience.  Some expected a more explicit instructions.  Some expected a more directed experience.  These are all fair points, but I think it's exceptionally important to define what kind of game The Witness is:

The Witness is a Puzzle Game.  You solve puzzles.  If solving puzzles is not your jam, or if you need a overarching narrative to keep you interested, then this is not your the game for you.  If the idea of solving clever and complicated puzzles that tend to ask a lot out of the player makes you excited, then this is a game you will probably enjoy!

I enjoyed The Witness immensely, but I knew what I was getting into:  A game about solving puzzles.

reviewText:
This game is so good I couldn't keep myself away from it for too long!

The atmosphere is amazing. I love the colour palettes the developers chose, and the way there is so much happening on this fairly small island. They packed so much stuff in there! It looks so meticulously designed!

The puzzles are quite well thought out. It takes this kind of path tracing puzzle concept and runs with it; it goes through many different rule sets all based on this one type of puzzle. The way in which it is done is awe-inspiring. I found myself excited whenever I figured out what one of those variations was.

The game definitely lived up to the promise of a challenge - nothing was given for free (or at least, not much). However, as a puzzle game fan (and adventure game fan) myself, I found that to be quite entertaining. I was often faced with a puzzle that I at first thought was impossible. However, in every case, I would come around to the answer. It was really cool how they managed to get the puzzle's rule set accross without actually saying anything. I love games that give me these mental exercises without holding my hand, but still make it just enough of a challenge to be solvable without breaking your brain.

The only drawback with the game (and it isn't a big one at all), is that some of the clips you find on the island are a little long. They vary from 10 minutes to more than an hour. Thankfully, though, there aren't that many to find. If you play this game, you'll know why I know about the lengths... ;) The videos overall (mixed with the audio clips strewn about the landscape) give you an interesting mix of perspectives on the human condition. However, I do feel that while they don't exactly fit within the context of this game, they do provide food for thought.

In short, I would recommend this game to any puzzle or adventure game fan out there. As some have mentioned, there isn't much of a story, but I really don't care. It gives just enough to be mysterious, and that's enough for me.

reviewText:
One of the most challenging and satisfying puzzle games I've ever played. It challenges all of your abilities. Not just problem solving, but observation and imagination as well. At times it feels a bit obtuse, and that can get frustrating, but if you take a break and come back later with a fresh perspective, you can eventually figure it all out. The audio logs and such are hit-and-miss on their own, but add to the enigma of the island as a whole. And if you haven't noticed by the screenshots, that island looks incredible. Every new environment is jaw dropping.

I completely forgot about this game on two seperate occasions during it's seemingly endless development. I thought maybe Jonathan Blow & his team might be a bit behind the times as far as indie games go after all this time, but I've been proven wrong. The Witness is uniquely fresh and strange, but also remarkably inviting.

Recommended for fans of  Myst, The Talos Principle, Antichamber, Braid

reviewText:
It's pretty much an update to MYST in the modern world. Well done! Many elements are there, as well as the atmosphere. They perfectly achieved what Braid did to side-scrollers.

On the puzzle side, I enjoyed most of the sets, the wonderful swamp more than the digging site with the reflections, the shadows of twigs more than the interchangeable apple trees. I hated some, especially those that were so obvious, afterwards, and I loved those that became more and more complex and required more backtracking, like those in the Endgame.

I would recommend it to anyone who liked Portal. Take your time to discover, and refrain from cheating (seriously! did it once, destroyed the experience...)

reviewText: This game is a masterpiece.  It takes the best elements of the puzzle/exploration genre (i.e. Myst, etc.) and completely eliminates the more frustrating elements of that genre.  For example, in Myst you could be stuck forever because you didn't realize some teeny-tiny pixel was a button that you needed to push.  The developers probably didn't even intend for that to be a hard puzzle, but you just didn't see it.  Well in The Witness every single puzzle is plainly displayed and very obvious.  Furthermore, the sequence of puzzles is obvious and the game does an incredible job of very fairly teaching you each rule you need to learn to solve each puzzle before later testing you on that knowledge.  This teaching was one of the more impressive elements of the game.  The end result is a type of puzzle where you could easily imagine the majority of them being in a straight puzzle game (no adventure or exploration, etc.) but that would be somewhat boring and The Witness has an excellent atmosphere of intrigue that makes you want to find out what is beyond the next gate.  The downside of this puzzle approach is that The Witness does not have the same immersive feeling as a game like Myst which had puzzles seamlessly integrated into the environment itself.  However, if that kind of immersive puzzle is something you love then The Witness actually has you covered there too!  I won't say anything that spoils the fun, but there is a whole set of puzzles that are not required to finish the game that do not show up on clearly marked panels...\n\nMy recommendation to anyone who plays this game: DO NOT look up walkthroughs!  Seriously, you can figure it out.  If you're stuck on a puzzle just walk away and come back another day.  I can't count the number of times I was so close to giving up and looking up a walkthrough and when I came back the next day I was able to figure it out.  I'll admit I did use one hint and that was for one of the bird call puzzles.  But most of the fun of this game is in the moments of finally figuring out a hard puzzle by yourself.

reviewText:
You must ask yourself if this game is for you. It's not for everyone. There's no action, items, or enemies. The game is ponderous, challenging, and vague. Not everyone wants to spend over 25 hours solving puzzles, and thats ok. But if puzzle games are interesting to you, The Witness is certainly one of the best. To like this game, you must enjoy and be satisfied with learning new concepts and experiencing breakthrough moments in your understanding. If this sounds good, just buy the game, its fantastic. If its not enough, maybe skip it (or challenge yourself).

This game is about puzzles, but it is also about learning, discovery and epistemology. In the end, it is about teaching you to solve its mazes while organically guiding you to moments of epiphany. While the game certainly takes itself seriously, I think that it deserves the attitude for how well it accomplishes its design goals. This game sticks to its morals and realizes them fully. The result is something beautifully unique that doesn't compromise if doing so would undermine its goals.

It surprised me how versatile the maze puzzles are. The simple concept of drawing a line through a grid from the start to the finish is complicated by gaps in the grid and symbols whose meaning you must learn through sets of puzzles designed for that purpose. Eventually you are solving problems with multiple sets of symbols that must be satisfied simultaneously, speaking a new sort of visual language.

Oh, and the visual are effing superb! Really, this game deserves to be played slowly, stop and look at all the pretty things (it may even be usefull...)
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Witness: Puzzle Dark Souls

Man, this game is fantastic!  Big fan of puzzle games from Myst, Riven, Journey Man Project, 7th Guest all the way up to the new puzzlers: Talos, Portal, Kairo, Antichamber, etc.  This is top 10 adventure/puzzle games easy.

Massive amount of content, 600+ puzzles, and I'm still trucking on with some puzzles left 80+ hours.

As for the backlash, well........it's pretty clear that the new generation of non-puzzlers have arrived; this is to be a rude awakening - it's definitely as hard as some of the old school adventure/puzzle games without the pixel hunting.

I plowed through the content with very few roadblocks although the extra puzzles will easily double the time of what is essentially a 40 hour full completion of the basic puzzles.

To the downvoters - you knew it wasn't Call of Duty.  Can't believe the flack this incredible game is getting.  Was the same with Dark Souls if I remember - harder gameplay = breakdowns.  And what is this need for a plot? Jesus.  I have yet to make any sense out of the story/plot - because there isn't any - you're trying too hard.

What's with the complaining about the puzzles? It's a puzzle game.  Hard to believe that getting stuck on a puzzle for longer than 10 minutes doesn't count as content any more.  I ran a dark souls boss for 5 hours until I nailed it.  Your weak! Weak!  Puzzle games aren't for the whiny or those who don't find puzzles entertaining - may want to stick with Uncharted, you filthy casual.  I kid. I kid.

Most fun Ive had in ages.  It's the ship door next. Gulp."

reviewText:
The Witness is Jonathan Blow's long-awaited Myst-like puzzle/adventure game.

Pros:
- Fantastic art direction
- Exceedingly (and nearly endlessly) brilliant variations on the puzzle theme
- Lots of secrets and hidden things
- Room to think about what the game means, similar to Braid
- Challenging but fair; rewards perception and thinking
- Did I mention lots and lots of well-designed puzzles
- That great feeling when you finally figure out the puzzle that has been stumping you for forever only to be stumped again by another one...theres lots of this here.

Neutral observations:
- No music for the most part
- This game is not for everyone. If you dont like puzzles very much you wont like this game.

Cons:
- Around .5% of the puzzles I found to be too much of a challenge or not clearly explained
- There are certain...philosophical elements scattered in the game which are supposed to add into the story, like Braid. Unfortunately Blow still has not grasped the distinction between crafting a narrative which is hidden but meaningful and one which is vague and borderline meaningless. Fortunately some of these are enjoyable enough in their own right but they distract from the rest of the game and make the story feel like its own separated fragment.
- Solving so many puzzles can be tiring after a while

Overall: Essential if you are into puzzle games. Worthwhile even if you're not. Get this.

reviewText:
Exploring the beautiful, huge, and complex world began to feel stale and empty when I realized that there's NOTHING to do in it, except for when there's giant, square tiles to click on.

I won't spoil it completely, but my favorite part of the whole game was when I found something sort of secret about the world involving the puzzle mechanics (which made me freak out because I was so desperately hoping for something mysterious and new to happen, although it never really helped me complete my journey so it never mattered, sadly).

This was a REALLY pretty game. Absolutely stunning. However, doing the same type of puzzles over and over with nothing interesting in-between quickly got old, and I felt like it was missing something crucial. A storyline, perhaps? Some sort of twist? What am I going to witness in this world that's so spectacular? Nothing but the world itself, really. In my opinion, that isn't really enough to be worth buying.
voteText: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The Witness is now officially my favorite game of all time. It takes a bit of getting used to, but the beautiful world, coupled with brilliant puzzles, and a mysterious world with few answers creates a game I have spent hours in and many more to come. Negative reviews of The Witness may state the game has no sense of progression, but I believe that the progression people seek is constant reward, with the game saying GOOD JOB or whatever. This game isn't like that, but what it is is a study on your own mind: a test to see if you are determined, logical, and observant enough to solve what Jonathan Blow and his development team has come up with. Since this game was announced, I had been eagerly waiting its arrival, and I am very pleased to say the seven years of waiting did not disappoint. Play The Witness, forget the price (if you can buy it on sale, even better), and envelop yourself in that world for at least a few hours. The Witness has hit just the right notes and I will always remember the time I spent in it. Yet again, I now deem The Witness my most favorite game of all time.

reviewText:
The perfect successor to Myst!

If you love solving puzzles and are looking for a game that will challenge your mind and your sanity, this is definitely worth your time.

The Witness takes a simple concept, that being mazes, and gradually introduces more and more depths, twists and mechanics along the way. There are over 600 different puzzles to be solved here and trust me, later on in the game they'll take you a while to figure out.

This game will make you feel like an utter genius one minute, and a complete idiot the next. 9/10

reviewText:
Somewhere around 19-20 hours, I got the 'ending' for the game.  I completed much more than was necessary by then, but there are definitely things in the world that I haven't completed yet.

I'm not a fan of the ending.  But I'm still enjoying the game.  Overall, I'd say it's been pretty great.

People who don't enjoy pure puzzles will likely not like this game.  It's not a game that rewards you for solving puzzles.  It's a game that throws puzzles at you and the reward is having solved them.  That said, puzzles do prevent you from progressing, so some might consider that a reward, but I'm betting more people don't get the feeling from solving the puzzles.

While I could see it taking another 80 hours to finish the rest of the game, it would be incredibly boring if that were the case.  If the rest of the game, as far as I can see, takes another 20 hours, I'd say that's as far as it could stretch and not turn tedious.  And it's quite possible that even that number is optimistic.

I consider myself a rather good puzzle solver, and most puzzles didn't take more than 30 seconds to a minute, and many were less than that, even.  Last I checked, I was at like 400-500+ puzzles solved.

reviewText: I'll admit that I'm not done with this game, as I'm sure many aren't either. At about 25 hours in, this is a game about trying to do puzzles, finding out why your answer is wrong, and learning all of the rules of the puzzles. I've never gotten to a puzzle that I couldn't finish because of this. Sometimes it takes pulling out a whiteboard and drawing potential paths, but this game never breaks its own rules and that's paramount in puzzle games.\n\nThis is a game that rewards  you, not only for concentration, but a serendipitious curiosity that is rare in new games. This game asks you to, above all else, exist on this island.

TL;DR: In short, the game does not have many puzzles that require much thought. In most cases instead the game just makes the actual act of solving the puzzle difficult.

If you're looking for a puzzle game that requires actual thought, get this instead: https://itunes.apple.com/de/app/pushy/id322110989

Here's the point where i personally gave up:

Ran into the sound puzzles. Puzzles where one has to draw lines at heights indicated by bird song. Doable. Then the game overlays cellphones, wood instruments and more birds. These were entirely impossible for me. Game provides no way to make them easier whatsoever, and has no compassion for people who aren't great of hearing.


---

Some more rambly details:

The game is basically a very beautiful, mostly static 3d landscape you walk around in. It might actually be kind of relaxing if that was the point, but the point of the game is puzzles.

The game's puzzles are largely not solved". There are a few exceptions

reviewText:
One of the most mind bending and ingenious puzzle games I have played in years, but there are a few things to watch out for.

Pros:
Loads of content, 500+ puzzles to find
Increasingly complex and interesting puzzle variety
Beautiful environments to explore
Secrets!
YMMV:
Some incredibly tough puzzles, very rewarding to work out though
May be impossible if you are sensory imapired
Frustration when stuck is part of the deal, being able to walk away and come back later is key
Cons:
Maze puzzles are 90% of the game
Do not expect a story of any kind, this is not Myst
Your only rewards for completing puzzles are more puzzles
Do not expect the game to tell you what to do, ever
Can feel a bit pretentious at times
I think you can see that you will either love or hate this game depending on your feelings towards the puzzles on offer. Personally I enjoyed every moment and was amazed as to the level that the simple mechanics were taken, each new area had at least one eurka" moment and the lack of hand-holding made the feeling of accomplishment all the more rewarding. Get this is you want an ingenious and devilish puzzle game that tests both your logic and understanding of the world you are exploring."

reviewText:
It should be stated up front that this is not a game for everyone. If you are into atmospheric games that's heavy on the puzzles without a lot of narrative, this is a game for you. Otherwise, I can't recommend it.

That said, this game is gorgeous. Just looking at the screenshots and videos should tell you that though. Not only that, but you can tell great care was taken in putting the whole island together. The environment around the island changes drastically between two area, yet every transition feels natural. And just looking around, you can find many hidden images by standing in the right spot (like say an octopus under the water made out of sand and rocks or a face in the trunk of a tree). Everything seems to have a purpose in how it was placed.

And then there are the puzzles. I spent a whopping 48 hours looking for, thinking on, and solving what the community believes to be every puzzle in the game. And let me tell you, these are hard. I don't know if I've ever played a game that pushed already taught mechanics to this degree of difficulty in such a fair manner. If anything new is dropped on you, there's a place to learn it.

This game is all exploration. You have to explore to learn. You have to explore to solve. You have to explore to do anything. And I loved ever minute of it. (Well, except the swamp, but that's just me.)

reviewText:
Let me first start off by saying... I just completed the final challenge in this game earlier today and I'm STILL coming down off the high that it gave me, already half a day later.  It was definitely a very difficult challenge, especially at the end, but games like these are all about perseverance and looking at things from every angle!  I've got a lot I could say about this game, but in true Witness fashion, let me first proceed by backing up... and start with explaining just what kind of game this is for those who might be interested in picking it up:

The Witness is, at its core, a puzzle game.  As others have stated in their reviews, this game is not for everyone... but NO puzzle game is.  So like I said, it is a puzzle game, but holy mother of god it is a GORGEOUS one!!  I have played many puzzle games before this one since I am a huge fan of the genre...  All were pretty unique experiences, and some are fairly simple-looking while others have beautiful graphics.  The Witness is one of the latter.  I found myself completely and consistently immersed in its simple yet gorgeoulsy rendered 3D environment.  Just looking around I couldn't help but apprecaite how every detail of the island is a carefully crafted work of art, but make no mistake... The Witness is a really hardcore puzzle game!  Almost all of the interaction with the various objects throughout the environment consists of solving maze-like puzzles by drawing the path with your cursor based on different rules and different shapes of maze.  I was truly impressed with the amount of diversity the developers were able to achieve with such a simple concept, and I really mean that!  These puzzles really are incredibly clever and immensely satisfying to solve... which is why I quickly found myself addicted to this game.

Due to the nature of the environment and the exploration aspect of The Witness, many might compare this game to the Myst series.  I, too, found many similar aspects between the two... such as the way you must carefully examine the environment around you for clues and extrapolating with previously obtained knowledge to solve puzzles which grant you access to new areas to explore... not to mention the fact that you are exploring a deserted island as a nameless, faceless observer with almost no narrative.  However, the puzzles themselves are vastly different and Myst DID have a narrative, however irrelevant it may have seemed at times.

The journey in this game is purely scientific in nature... it is about learning and then applying your newly acquired knowledge in the process to learn more!  It's also worth noting that there is some really fantastic voice-over work done by some top-notch voice actors in this game, but without spoiling anything I'll just say that its inclusion is less relevant to the game itself and more about adding some perspective to the experience of playing it... or just interesting philosophical fluff, however you choose to interpret it (also, it is completely optional to listen to it).  There is a lot about this game that is open to interpretation actually, but if you're into strictly puzzle games, don't let that turn you off!  You can still enojy the hell out of solving these puzzles even if you don't care about the beautiful environment or the philosophical framework in which it sits.

Lastly, this game is from the same creative mind that brought us Braid, another fantastic puzzle game that I greatly enjoyed for its clever implementation of gameplay mechanics and devious puzzle design.  While The Witness is a VERY different gameplay experience compared to Braid, I could easily use the same description for both... so in my humble opinion this is another smash hit from the now-legendary-if-he-wasn't-already Jonathan Blow!

Closing statements: If you enjoy challenging your brain with puzzles, you HAVE to try The Witness!

reviewText: I enjoyed this game a great deal, but at certain times I found puzzle rules and basics were thrown out the door.  The sun  puzzle at the Quarry to get the ramp in the sawmill up totally disregarded the suns being in pairs and needing to separate them according to color.  Every sun puzzle up to that point followed the rules of suns being in pairs and different colored stars seperated.  But in that case ignored.  Took me forever till i solved it by accident.\n\nAgain inside the mountain they broke rules where the stars were not paired in the puzzle and the only solution was star to be paired with another cube.  This change the rules as you go approach taken in this game angered me a great deal.  It is why I can love and at times hate puzzle games.  However most times the game is faithful to its own rules for each puzzle type.   There is alot to explore and see.  Secret places that are hard to find.  I think this game is the first true successor of sorts to the Myst franchise.  It's definitely worth $40 dollars.

reviewText: The Witness is truly a wonder of unified game design. Every aspect -- art, mechanics, audio, pacing, visual narrative, teaching -- is designed with regard to, and to work with, each of the others to lead the player toward the conclusions that drive the experience. It fully explores the mechanics involved, in ways that are simultaneously unexpected and completely natural.\nThis is the single best puzzle game I've ever played; it's probably one of the best puzzle games ever made.

reviewText:
Exploring the beautiful, huge, and complex world began to feel stale and empty when I realized that there's NOTHING to do in it, except for when there's giant, square tiles to click on.

I won't spoil it completely, but my favorite part of the whole game was when I found something sort of secret about the world involving the puzzle mechanics (which made me freak out because I was so desperately hoping for something mysterious and new to happen, although it never really helped me complete my journey so it never mattered, sadly).

This was a REALLY pretty game. Absolutely stunning. However, doing the same type of puzzles over and over with nothing interesting in-between quickly got old, and I felt like it was missing something crucial. A storyline, perhaps? Some sort of twist? What am I going to witness in this world that's so spectacular? Nothing but the world itself, really. In my opinion, that isn't really enough to be worth buying.
voteText: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The Witness is now officially my favorite game of all time. It takes a bit of getting used to, but the beautiful world, coupled with brilliant puzzles, and a mysterious world with few answers creates a game I have spent hours in and many more to come. Negative reviews of The Witness may state the game has no sense of progression, but I believe that the progression people seek is constant reward, with the game saying GOOD JOB or whatever. This game isn't like that, but what it is is a study on your own mind: a test to see if you are determined, logical, and observant enough to solve what Jonathan Blow and his development team has come up with. Since this game was announced, I had been eagerly waiting its arrival, and I am very pleased to say the seven years of waiting did not disappoint. Play The Witness, forget the price (if you can buy it on sale, even better), and envelop yourself in that world for at least a few hours. The Witness has hit just the right notes and I will always remember the time I spent in it. Yet again, I now deem The Witness my most favorite game of all time.

reviewText: I've spent over 40 hours playing this game, and I wish I could express how amazing it is. It's not a game for everyone. It's puzzle after puzzle and they get harder and harder. So hard, in fact, that you can spend a good 30 minutes trying to figure one of them out. But the puzzles are NEVER cheap, they are beyond clever, and as you get better and better, you start to realize what's going on. The game is trying to communicate with you, and it actually has a lot to say.\n\nDo not skip this game. If you get this game, and you're stuck at a puzzle, don't give up. Explore the world and come back to that puzzle later. Once you start to explore and begin to understand, you'll feel a strong attachment to the world, and you'll never want to leave.

reviewText:
This is a love-it-or-hate-it thing.

Yes, the whole game is maze puzzles. Yes, there's barely any explicit narrative -- and the little bit that *is* there is buried very, very deep. I went 50 hours in The Witness before I felt I understood what the island was, or why I was there. And there's still some doubt there, frankly.

And... none of that bothers me. I found the puzzles tremendously engaging. I felt like a genius when I solved them, and discovering the endless, clever twists on the mechanics was a constant delight. I was happy when my puzzle-solving prowess was, inevitably, rewarded with more puzzles to solve. That's what I wanted to do: it's just like an FPS game rewarding you with a bigger gun, and more things to shoot with it.

So this all hinges on whether or not you personally enjoy the puzzle mechanics of The Witness. If you do, the game will absolutely fascinate you; if you don't, it'll seem an interminable slog. I don't think there's much middle ground there, and there's just no way to know until you try it.

If $40 seems like too big a risk, there's no shame in waiting for a sale. For me, though, the game was worth every penny, and then some.

reviewText:
This review contains no spoilers.

Warning: I would be very cautious about reading other reviews and being robbed of some of the best experiences the game has to offer.

The Witness is hands down the best puzzle game I have ever played.

The bite-sized puzzles never feel too imposing - you just about never look at a puzzle and think I don't think I'm up for that. I think I'll come back to it tomorrow.".

The essence of the gameplay is the combination of those basic logic puzzles (the fundamental concepts of the puzzle boards) and a huge variety of environmental complications like colored panes of glass and tree limbs and erased lines and more. No other game mixes environmental puzzles and symbolic logic puzzles together so masterfully.

Another consequence of this unifying concept of the puzzle board is that you always know when you're looking at one. The game almost entirely lacks that Myst situation where you're wandering around unsure of where the next puzzle is. It also lacks the Myst problem of puzzles that are available
date: but impossible to solve until some other puzzle is solved first.\n\nThe method of teaching the "rules" of the symbols on the puzzle boards through carefully designed challenges without ever using any explicit explanation is downright brilliant. They're carefully designed to make you think you understand a rule
recommended: to give you a series of puzzles where the rule you've come up with will work
hoursPlayed:
but then to suddenly confront you with a puzzle where you have to rethink. You'll frequently discover that you convinced yourself something was impossible without ever seeing evidence of that.

And none of the puzzles ever require guess-and-check.

If you're guessing and checking
voteText: you're making a mistake. You can play Sudoku by guessing numbers and seeing how far they get you - you'll eventually solve any Sudoku puzzle that way - but you're not really playing Sudoku if you do that. So it is with The Witness.\n\nOnce you understand all the pieces of the puzzle
helpfulPercent: it is always possible to solve it completely deductively. Learning the different ways to do this is a huge part of the game. Many complaints about the game center around the idea that the reviewer "learned all the rules" and then just spent hours and hours boringly brute-forcing puzzles. Learning the "rules" is just the start. The bulk of the game is not spent learning the rules
votesHelpful: but learning the logical consequences of the rules that allow you to deductively solve puzzles. It isn't just about learning the rules of the dots
votesTotal: it's about learning that the rules of the dots imply that certain configurations are impossible. After you learn the rules
votesFunny: the subsequent boards will be about teaching you these implications.\n\nThe audio logs and videos can feel a bit preachy at times
commentsCount: but having listened to all of them now
column16: I understand a lot beter what purpose they served. They can initially come across as a pretentious affectation
column17: like some college student going around spouting random philosophy quotes to seem "deep"
column18: but in time I think the game does actually reveal a fairly legitimate depth to what it's trying to express.\n\nAnd the final challenge
column19: past the "end" of the game
column20: is downright beautiful. While opinions may differ
column21: I also found the reward for completing it to be far more worthwhile than the final rewards in most other games.\n\nFundamentally though
column22:
The Witness is a game about changes in perception. It's a game about looking at something again and again and then suddenly and very viscerally seeing it in a totally different light. Sometimes that's puzzles - sometimes it's re-examining how you think a symbol works or how you reason about a certain kind of puzzle. Other times the shift in perspective is more profound.

Penultimate warning: You will almost certainly want some paper and a pen. Maybe even some scissors.

Final warning: If you use a guide to get through much of the game
column23: there is a very real possibility
column24: thanks to a brilliant pieces of design near the end
column25: that you will find yourself unable to complete it."

reviewText: The Witness stands alone among recent releases as a pure puzzle game. As good puzzle games should do each element and mechanic is added in its simplest form and difficulty is achieved through iteration and mixing of different mechanics in logical, but sometimes tricky, ways. The closest thing to a text tutorial the game contains is the controls menu. While game options are sparse and the experience has some problems for some computer setups it receives reasonable support.\n\nThe Witness is stunning and picturesque and its puzzles once mastered are deeply rewarding, and while some content in the form of audio and video logs leans towards nuage fare it is at the very least presented thoughtfully.

reviewText:
The Witness is a puzzle game with a minimal amount of story but an absolutely beautiful world to explore, with an excellent merging of the puzzles you solve and the environment you're in.

It is unabashedly a puzzle game, and it has extremely well-crafted and insanely difficult puzzles, while still providing a natural learning progression without hand-holding and annoying tutorials. You start by solving easy puzzles, then harder, then harder still. The reward for solving puzzles is most often more puzzles, like the games Hexcells, Hook, or Snakebird. Occasionally you find audio logs that give philosophical perspective from famous thinkers like Einstein, Nicholas of Cusa or Heisenberg.

But make no mistake about it - this is a puzzle game, and like the other games I listed, the reward for tackling a grueling puzzle is solving it. Some people will not like the lack of RPG Puzzle Experience Points™ or new and exciting guns with which to take down tougher puzzles, but it's not that kind of game.  The game is about taking in the surrounding and using it to solve puzzles.

The puzzles themselves are brilliant. Even though they all take the same general form (You need to find a path through a maze) there is an ENORMOUS amount of variety. Furthermore they are brilliantly paced and the game does an excellent job of teaching you the rules non-verbally. You'll come up across two or three puzzles with a new symbol, think you understand it, but then the game will force you to deal with a puzzle that makes you tweak the way you thought it worked.  Regardless of what some detractors say, there is not a single puzzle in the game that 'breaks the rules'. It is perfectly consistent.

Some real criticisms: The trailer promises a story about regaining your memory, but that is absolutely 100% not in the game. Some of the areas are incredibly unfriendly to people with disabilities like color-blindness or deafness. Some of the quick but tough puzzles turn off on wrong guesses (to stop people from bruteforcing them) and you need to resolve the previous puzzle (the solution remains on the panel, so it's not difficult) so that can be annoying.

However these flaws are minor compared to the excellent puzzle crafting, the beauty of the island, and the mind-opening fusion of the two. This game is heartily recommended to people who like puzzle games.

Small spoiler for people who don't get it": If all you've done is walk from puzzle to puzzle
date: making guesses until you move on
recommended: and then finish the game without looking around
hoursPlayed: you're going to have a bad time. The environment MATTERS. Go to the mountain. Take a look down at the river. Open your eyes."

reviewText:
The Witness is one of the best puzzle games I've ever played. It's a challenging puzzle game, yet like the best puzzle games, it makes the player feel like a genius for solving its puzzles, and it was never frustrating.

It's a masterpiece for how a single mechanic can still teach and feel rewarding after 40 hours. This mechanic, essentially drawing colored lines on a grid, is made constantly fresh by introducing new rules to the player for solving these puzzles. In fact, the biggest challenge is often simply figuring out what the rules for each puzzle element are. Often, careful observation of the environment is required, as visual and audio clues may guide you to a solution.

The game takes place on a beautiful, deserted island. It's rich in color, and yours to explore, almost in its entirety, from the moment you start. What works so well about the puzzle solving is that when you get stuck, and you often will, you can simply go to another area and try new puzzles there. You can skip many of the puzzles and still complete the game. Exploring one part of the island sometimes reveals a way to solve another puzzle that you couldn't figure out. Sometimes, the quiet, contemplative nature of the island puts you in the right frame of mind to solve another puzzle.

Perspective, finally, is another major feature of the game, and when I finally saw it clicking in the puzzle and in the world itself, I was amazed.

I was worried that the story would rub me the wrong way, as the developer's previous game had quite a few pretentious story elements (and one very clever twist). Here, though, all the written or spoken story elements are more or less optional. There are hidden audio and visual clips to be found or unlocked. I never felt like there was some hidden meaning that was being kept from me; rather, they were all interesting moments that I was free to interpret as I choose. I did feel that there were one or two major themes of the game, but it's left up to the player's own interpretation.

The Witness smoothly teaches its mechanics to the player, and without needing words it does this teaching in a way that makes it feel like a discovery that the player made, not something explicitly authored by the developer. Out hundreds of puzzles solved, only a couple felt unfair to me.

I strongly recommend The Witness for the meditative calm  of its aesthetics and the feeling of quiet success that comes from its excellent puzzles.

reviewText: The Witness is truly a wonder of unified game design. reviewText:
Alright, here's a spoiler free thing you need to know before buying the game:

Good stuff:  - Amazing puzzle game.
- You get exactly what you've heard in all official publications and reviews: it's a game about epiphany, and there will be epiphany. If you read more than this line about any of the puzzles, it's spoilers.
- Beautiful world, I loved to wonder aimlessly through it and just enjoy the view.

The Big Bad Stuff. There is no explicit story! People expected this. All story elements you hear are interesting, but disjointed. You don't have to agree with all of them, especially since sometimes they offer conflicting views. There's a lot of implicit storytelling in there (through architecture for example).

Bottom line, the story is not the point of this game. There are cool story elements, but the story should NOT be the reason you get this.


Other bad stuff:
- Probably unplayable if you are colourblind.
- Settings are very rudimentary. No control over keyboard layouts, game resolution...
- No accessibility settings. Admittedly, Jon Blow recently tweeted that he's working on some accessibility features (mostly for motion sickness).
- Spoilers for this game are worse than spoilers in general. The puzzles are designed to evoke specific feelings and experiences. Spoilers completely ruin those.
- I really wish there was an Extras" option in the menu. At minimum to replay all discovered audio logs."

reviewText:
Comprised of ingenious line puzzles and tests of observation, The Witness presents serious players with a challenge of curiousity.  While there are moments of frustration from lack of understanding, the powerfully epiphanic moments of discovery more than make up for them - that is, if you're observant enough.  Many of the bigger moments come hours of gameplay in.

I also really liked the realism in player movement - a realistic shadow, sense of inertia, and a other little elements make you feel like you're really there, exploring.  They were appropriate touches that I've never seen before.  The beautiful graphics are also always a welcome sight.

Like so much of the game, the narrative itself is expertly embedded in the environment, and it too is very rewarding and profound.  If you're seeking a true challenge like you've never experienced, you may pick up The Witness without hesitation.

P.S. Fans of The Talos Principle - this is a must-buy.

reviewText:
The Witness is a puzzle game with a minimal amount of story but an absolutely beautiful world to explore, with an excellent merging of the puzzles you solve and the environment you're in.

It is unabashedly a puzzle game, and it has extremely well-crafted and insanely difficult puzzles, while still providing a natural learning progression without hand-holding and annoying tutorials. You start by solving easy puzzles, then harder, then harder still. The reward for solving puzzles is most often more puzzles, like the games Hexcells, Hook, or Snakebird. Occasionally you find audio logs that give philosophical perspective from famous thinkers like Einstein, Nicholas of Cusa or Heisenberg.

But make no mistake about it - this is a puzzle game, and like the other games I listed, the reward for tackling a grueling puzzle is solving it. Some people will not like the lack of RPG Puzzle Experience Points™ or new and exciting guns with which to take down tougher puzzles, but it's not that kind of game.  The game is about taking in the surrounding and using it to solve puzzles.

The puzzles themselves are brilliant. Even though they all take the same general form (You need to find a path through a maze) there is an ENORMOUS amount of variety. Furthermore they are brilliantly paced and the game does an excellent job of teaching you the rules non-verbally. You'll come up across two or three puzzles with a new symbol, think you understand it, but then the game will force you to deal with a puzzle that makes you tweak the way you thought it worked.  Regardless of what some detractors say, there is not a single puzzle in the game that 'breaks the rules'. It is perfectly consistent.

Some real criticisms: The trailer promises a story about regaining your memory, but that is absolutely 100% not in the game. Some of the areas are incredibly unfriendly to people with disabilities like color-blindness or deafness. Some of the quick but tough puzzles turn off on wrong guesses (to stop people from bruteforcing them) and you need to resolve the previous puzzle (the solution remains on the panel, so it's not difficult) so that can be annoying.

However these flaws are minor compared to the excellent puzzle crafting, the beauty of the island, and the mind-opening fusion of the two. This game is heartily recommended to people who like puzzle games.

Small spoiler for people who don't get it": If all you've done is walk from puzzle to puzzle
date: making guesses until you move on
recommended: and then finish the game without looking around
hoursPlayed: you're going to have a bad time. The environment MATTERS. Go to the mountain. Take a look down at the river. Open your eyes."

reviewText:
Oh boy...this is a tough one to review.

At the time of this review I only put 1 hour into The Witness.  I believe after scouring most of the island and doing alot of the puzzles, I can make an accurate first impression.  So you load in and find yourself in a tunnel.  You walk through it and find yourself in a beautiful fort area.  The graphics here were really well done.  Very colorful and differentiated.  After solving the first puzzle, you leave this closed area and can traverse the island freely.  After seeing a few more puzzles and completing them you begin to see a pattern.  All the puzzles use the same mechanic. You draw a line from one area to another area, and usually have to cover all the dots along the way.  I've seen this before in a tablet game called Lyne.

So the whole time, you are walking around admiring the scenery.  You notice there's no soundtrack, no monologue or narration.  No notes, books or posters...basically what I'm getting at here is, nothing to tell you about where you are or what this place is.  In a way, this can be helpful to the overall immersion of the island.  For me however, growing up with games like Myst and Riven, this was a deterent.  I never felt immersed in TW.  I just felt bored after that first hour.  I found that none of the puzzles made any sense in their placement.  You've got a shed area here, giving you 5 screens of the same puzzle that just gets harder.  Then over there, maybe 50 ft away, you've got a tree puzzle with the same line mechanic on different screens.  Then another 100 ft down a path, you've got a laser puzzle.  There is no lore.  It just feels like an island of puzzles condensed in a small area.

I will give TW credit where credit is due.  Some of the puzzles are difficult and you feel a sense of accomplishment after completing them.  But with a price tag 0f 40 USD, I don't think this game is worth it.  Some polish needs to be done.  Like in the very beginning fort region, you can just walk through a sofa.  I feel like if they just added some music or more sound effects other than the wind, it would be a lot more immersive.  Maybe change up the puzzle design here and there.  Some of the puzzles require you to just look at the environment.  No spoilers, but the tree puzzle is a lot easier if you look at the placement of the trees.

In the end, I just didn't feel like I was a part of this world.  Almost felt like it was a tech demo that the developer of Braid made to see if he could do a puzzle game.  I wouldn't even call this an adventure game.  Once the price comes down to 20 USD I'd say pick it up.

reviewText:
The Witness is one of those games that’s hard to describe due to spoilers. In the most basic sense, it’s a puzzle game in which you interact with panels that are simple mazes, but really, the game gets so much more complex. Every area of the island in The Witness has a set of rules that govern the puzzles found there. You will learn what those rules are through what you could say are tutorial puzzles. Some later puzzles in areas will draw from the rules of other areas, so you start mixing two, three, four, etc… rule sets together and this results in some seriously complex puzzles.

Again, I cannot say too much as I don’t want to spoil anything, but many of these puzzles got so complex that I found myself grabbing a pen and some paper and actually writing notes and drawing diagrams. I took more notes while playing The Witness than I did while working on my Master’s degree. One puzzle, not due to the difficulty of it, but due to how it’s presented to the player, gave me a headache. This isn’t entirely bad and I can’t really explain why, again due to spoilers, but I just want to try and let you know as much as I can without spoiling, that the game does really spice things up and is far more than just solving some simple mazes.

I should also add that I played The Witness in a sort of co-op mode. I played it along with a buddy of mine and we went from puzzle to puzzle, area to area in our own respective game while we communicated via TeamSpeak. Where one of us struggled, the other helped. This made it so that we never had to resort to using any online walkthroughs. We never really lost that sense of accomplishment in solving the puzzles by having to cheat online.

The Witness is a game that will make you feel like a genius just as many times as it makes you feel like an idiot. It will haunt your dreams and warp your brain once you’ve finished it. You will start to see things in the real world and you will want to interact with them as you had in The Witness. The is most likely my favorite game of 2016, I’m sure it will have a place in my top 10 games of the last decade, and it is even in the running for one of my favorite gaming experiences of all time.

5/5

reviewText: The Witness is a work of true genius, and there's really nothing else like it. At first it appears to be nothing but a series of maze puzzles, although they are ingeniously constructed. As you progress through the game you discover that the entire island and virtually every part of the environment is part of a grand, interconnected meta-puzzle. Not a single rock, tree or building is placed without purpose. It's a mind-blowing piece of game design. If you enjoy difficult (but always fair) puzzles, I cannot recommend this highly enough.

reviewText:
The Witness sets out to be a modern day Myst. In that regards it had succeeded. Set on a mysterious island, you wander around completing puzzles. Rather impressively, these puzzles are all variants on the same mechanic, drawing lines on a grid. Don't let that simplicity fool you, these are hard puzzles that will leave you cursing the name of Johnathon Blow, the creator of The Witness.

Like a teacher, Johnathon Blow will gently lead you through the mechanics so that you learn not just to solve the puzzles, but to understand them. A key difference in that brute forcing through them or randomly guessing will be punished. With many areas to explore, each with its own unique take on the line drawing mechanics, it always felt like that even if I was stuck somewhere, I could go somewhere else and bang my head against a different wall. All I can say is, change your perspective and be observant of the environment.

One could even suggest that the island is like a metroidvania game, where the “item” is the knowledge you learn from each of the regions.

This game is a chain of moments where you go “Aha!” and suddenly understand the key. While you might not be physically lifting that item above your head to the world like in Zelda, you are essentially doing that mentally. I am often reminded of Fez when playing this game. Although Fez has that one moment where suddenly you see the code of the matrix, this game has a lot more (although slightly lesser) moments. Then again, it can still surprise you and make you open your eyes to wonder just what were you missing this whole time and what else might be hiding in plain sight.

Despite really enjoying this game, I did find a few pieces to dislike. While I can understand the choice in there being no music in this game, I disagree with it completely. But this is something that can be easily fixed by throwing some relaxing music on the music player. There are also certain classes of puzzles which some people might have a really hard time with. The “story” of The Witness is also very subtle and out of the way. Indeed the ending you get is rather disappointing. But it is a testament to the quality of the game that I didn't mind this all that much, helped very much by some of puzzles in the final area. Indeed the journey is much better than the destination.

Even if all you get is the first ending after 25 hours, it is still a brilliant game that is well worth the asking price. But if you wish to delve deep into the depths of the mystery of The Witness, it can still be worth your while.

reviewText:
I was expecting Myst or at least something like Myst which would expose a story as puzzles are completed. The Witness is not that. Instead it's back to back maze puzzles that never really seem to do anything. Solve a bunch of puzzles to open something, then solve another puzzle that looks like it's going to do something, then nothing. I've only been playing for around 5 hours now and this has happened to me several times. Even when I do complete puzzles there's been no big payoff so far which has killed my interest.

There's also no plot and if you're expecting something to keep you going beyond another puzzle which may or may not do something it's not here. I thought I might have been missing something so I started reading spoiler reviews and there's no plot here. There's no clues, no memories, nothing, just maze puzzles. I'd go as far as to call the description for this game deceptive based on what I've seen so far.

I want my $40 back.

reviewText:
One of the most challenging and satisfying puzzle games I've ever played. It challenges all of your abilities. Not just problem solving, but observation and imagination as well. At times it feels a bit obtuse, and that can get frustrating, but if you take a break and come back later with a fresh perspective, you can eventually figure it all out. The audio logs and such are hit-and-miss on their own, but add to the enigma of the island as a whole. And if you haven't noticed by the screenshots, that island looks incredible. Every new environment is jaw dropping.

I completely forgot about this game on two seperate occasions during it's seemingly endless development. I thought maybe Jonathan Blow & his team might be a bit behind the times as far as indie games go after all this time, but I've been proven wrong. The Witness is uniquely fresh and strange, but also remarkably inviting.

Recommended for fans of  Myst, The Talos Principle, Antichamber, Braid

reviewText:
The Witness was made for me.

I love puzzles, and I'm a sucker for colourful worlds.
Okay I'll admit it. I'm a fan, I've been waiting for this game since 2009 when I saw concept art.
I will say my wait was worth it. However, this game is not for everyone. I have enjoyed my time with this game even if there was a bit of pain involved. Without spoiling anything the main thing I learned in the first few hours is puzzles just lead to more puzzles and if you get stuck simply stop and move on. This game is simply a long set of tough logic puzzles with a world around it. If your okay with this, You will love the witness.

I'm recommending this game for people like me who will enjoy this game. I know some people don't agree with me but I feel like The Witness is a better Myst. I was never much of a fan of Myst. I feel the Witness is a much better game when it comes to helping you find your goal. Even if the journy there is a tough one. I will finish this game I'll update my review when its done.

Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
I bought The Witness yesterday, and I've completed 249 of the game's puzzles in approximately 7.5 hours. There are still quite a few areas I haven't unlocked, and a few puzzles that I'm completely baffled by, but generally speaking, the game gives you enough freedom to keep discovering new areas and learning about different game mechanics in a way that allows you to progress continuously. There are several areas which I've finished completely, which taught some of the simpler mechanics that are built on in later puzzles.

I want to give a little context on the way you learn about puzzle elements in this game, because I've seen some misconceptions in other reviews. The simplest puzzles are just moving a dot to connect a line from A to B, but quickly the game will start to introduce different symbols into the puzzles, each of which has a function and dictates something about the way you need to solve the puzzle.

This is the important part: There is a tutorial area for each puzzle element that holds your hand through learning how it works.

If you come across a puzzle that seems way too hard for you, then it probably is. The game is not encouraging you to try to guess the answer and get really frustrated. It's giving you a sign that you haven't learned the right tools to solve it yet, and you should be looking somewhere else. Every puzzle element, from black and white squares, to spiky dots, to a little tri-force looking thing that changes how different puzzle regions act, to things that look like Tetris blocks, every one of these elements is explained in a series of very basic puzzles (starting with just one or two squares as opposed to the usual 5x5 grid) that explains the mechanic. The rules, once you learn them, do not change. They are not arbitrary. They work the same way every time. There is a lot of challenge in finding a solution that fits all the conditions imposed by the different puzzle elements, but there is no guesswork.

It's unfortunate to see a lot of reviewers quitting after an hour and a half of playtime because they got really frustrated with something they didn't understand and want a refund for the game. My own feeling is that the game does a really good job of slowly introducing you to new elements, as long as you just walk around and look for simpler puzzles before going straight to trying the most complicated-looking thing you can find. The game even turns off the puzzle panels if you try to brute-force an answer to a puzzle you can't solve yet--- take the hint.

A few other things. The graphics are beautiful, with a very colorful, almost cel-shaded style. The different biomes of the island are each distinct and offer an impressive diversity of scenery, with each location having a different mood, and often with puzzle mechanics that relate loosely to the area (one region, overlooking a wide bay of calm water, teaches puzzles about reflection). The sound is minimal but effective; there are a few puzzles that actually require sound to complete, and because the rest of the soundtrack is relatively sparse, the auditory clues jumped out at me quickly. The one place where I think the game falters is in story, in that there really isn't one, even (at least as far as I've gotten) to be pieced together from the audio recordings and videos that can be found around the island. Myst or Riven this is not--- the game has a lot of atmosphere, but it doesn't have a narrative. As a fan of games with strong stories and generally of fiction with detailed world-building, it does seem like a little bit of a missed opportunity. But overall, I've really enjoyed my time with the game so far, and I'm looking forward to playing more.

I'd rate this game an 8/10.

reviewText:
Edit: A more in depth review, now that I played a bit.

The Witness is a puzzle game that I personally only recommend for the most hardcore puzzle fan.

You wake up on an island that seems to be completely empty. You have to explore it and figure out why you are on there, and what happened.

The story is pretty light. Aside from some voice messages and videos of psychological and philosophical nature, there isn't really much story to speak of until, maybe, the end (I am not there yet).

You progress through the island by solving the same type of puzzle over and over. Now, I am actually impressed by the amount of variations this game has for just the same type ofpuzzle. It starts off easy - draw a line from a starting point to an end point. As the game progresses, new symbols will be introduced that make solving these puzzles way harder, and sometimes even the environment will take part in the solution. For having only one type of puzzle, the game varies it a lot, keeping you busy and on your toes.

The puzzles themselves are generally on the harder side, but if you love puzzles, you will want to solve them all without looking into a walkthrough. Trust me, the experience is better that way.

Now, it is of course not all gold and sunshine. Here are my personal pros and cons for the game:

Pro:
+Graphics

The graphics are nice and sufficient. The island has lush colours, the graphic style is detailed enough without being overbearing, and everything is generally nice to look at and resourceful enough to work on any type of graphics card, really.

+Puzzles/Creativity

While the game only has one type of basic puzzle, it varies so much over the course of its 500+ puzzles that it has more variation in it than 10 types of puzzles could ever hope to achieve. Symbols, dots, tetris pieces and much more will make every area you explore a little different and keep you on your toes.

+Sounds

The sounds are well done. The footsteps are the primary sound you will hear, and they are just as satisfying to listen to as the wirring of machinery after a solved puzzle, or the buzzing of an activated computer panel.

+Secrets

The island has a lot of secret puzzles and secret locations. Exploring it is in general very fun and rewarding.

+Voice Messages

I like the voice messages in the game. While they are all only quotes of famous philosophers, scientists and the like, the people reading them really bring in some atmosphere. They do a great job, especially since everything else is so quiet.

Eh:

-+No Hints

There are no real hints or a way to progress should you ever not understand a puzzle. Now, the entire game is logical, and everything can be solved with logic, but should you ever not get something, then you can either explore somewhere else, or, if you don't understand a symbol, look at a walkthrough. It can be frustrating, but that is not necessarily a con - it makes you have to think about things.

-+No Music

There is no music in the game. Aside from the sound, everything is quiet. Some say it helps build up atmosphere, some find it annoying. It is up to you.

-+Claustrophobia

The game feels downright claustrophobic at times, which is weird. The island holds a lot of structures like castles, deserts, houses, and so on, but sometimes it feels so cramped full of things that it seems unnecessary. That could have been avoided by just making the island a bit larger.

Cons:

-No Map

This is probably my personal worst point. There is a fast travel system by using a boat you unlock at some point, and it shows a map - but there is no map you can call on at any point. The island itself isn't huge, but there are so many things to discover that a map would be really useful at times - the game is kept minimalistic for a reason, yes, but that doesn't mean it isn't annoying.

-No story (to speak of)

Aside from, what I heard, the end, the entire game has no story, really. Yes, apparently something happened on this island, but until the end, you won't know what - that can make solving puzzles feel meaningless.

-No reward

Aside from progressing over the island (sometimes), a lot of the puzzles don't have more rewards, except more puzzles. The reward is, I suppose, getting to solve them. Which is why I recommend the game only for diehard puzzle fans.

Overall, I think it is a game worth playing, but only if you love puzzles, can deal with a(n apparent) nonexistent story and no music, and like the atmosphere of exploring an abandoned island.

My personal rating: 7/10
