reviewText:
When I had my first oh my god moment after exploring enough, it actually startled me.

This review may be premature, but it's definitely worth recommending if you enjoy exploratory puzzle games the likes of MOTAS (the Mystery of Time and Space), but *moreso* if you enjoyed Antichamber.
There are a number of other indie puzzle games I'm dying to mention, but I hope you'll remember some of them when you stumble on what prompted me to write this immediately.

Beautiful art style and importantly: ART DIRECTION. I can already see why this game took so much time to make.
The philosophical aspect is relevant to the game and inspires curiousity.

The game absolutely does have tutorials, but allows you to find them and revisit old puzzles in a natural flow that kept me from being stumped so far.

Supplemental Post-Game

Still enjoyed the game overall, but there were some puzzles whose design were straight up frustrating and was glad to avoid having to solve. Aids such as photoshop were a massive help with some of those, but I don't know if that was intended as a solution, given the game was designed around the PS4 first (as far as I can tell)...

In any case, I still highly recommend this game.

It is still narratively thin, but I believe that its thematic strength and how it's married to the gameplay more than makes up for what a lot of people believe is plot vagueness.

reviewText:
This is an interesting specimen. It's very similar to Myst, in that it's an island filled with puzzles. However, while Myst's puzzles are all combination locks with a note hidden somewhere, The Witness' puzzles all require some serious grey matter.

The Witness' gameplay is incredibly simple. A first-person game where you explore an island and solve puzzles. These puzzles all take the form of maze panels. Each maze has a set of different mechanics. These mechanics, depending on where you start, are very simplistic, at first so you can get your bearings and understand how these mechanics work. The mechanics become more and more complicated and even mix into each other.

The puzzles are definitely the best part of the game. Not only do they become more complicated, but the way you find the solutions are absolutely mind-boggling. The island is crawling with clues. Not in the form of notes, but in the form of the island's decor. The plants, the rock formations, the architectures...almost everything on the island is a clue. Look closely! These puzzles are incredibly well-designed and implemented.

The game is also completely open. Each area of the island is yours to explore. This design choice also benefits the player if they are stuck on a puzzle, allowing them to walk away, clear their heads, and/or look to new puzzles to solve if you want. The game's setting is absolutely beautiful. Each part of the island is completely distinctive and wildly imaginative. A looming fortress, a forest set in eternal autumn, a beautiful orchard, a bamboo forest that could serve as a panda preserve, Journey-esque desert, and many more that I wish to not spoil.
I have yet to 100% complete this game, but I'm fully absorbed in it's incredibly complex design.

However, this game lacks a story (as far as I know and if it does, please don't spoil it for me). The game has several audio logs scattered about, but they're all real-world quotes that have no context.

This game leaves me feeling both befuddled, confused, frustrated, and fulfilled when I find the solution (Though, I often need a pad of graph paper on-hand. In fact, I have a pad specifically for this game. The puzzles are extremely well designed, they're simple to complete, yet complex in execution, and absolutely beautiful to look at. If you're a fan of deep, intricate games, I highly recommend it

reviewText:
Okay, this game isn't going to be everyone's cup of tea; it's hard as hell and some people might just brush the puzzles off as being dumb minigames that belong on an iPad.  I can see where those people are coming from but there's so much more going on here.

First off, let's state the obvious: The visuals are gorgeous.  Like this is probably the best looking game I've ever played, it's so pretty it blows my mind.

This game will NOT hold your hand in any way shape or form.  You can accidentally end up in areas where you shouldn't be and won't have a single hope of knowing how to solve the puzzles there.  Even though the puzzle mechanic of drawing lines on a grid remains the same, the game slowly introduces new different ways that the puzzles work, but each time a new thing is added you essentially have to figure out how it works yourself with no help!  Sometimes it's obvious and other times you'll scratch your head and feel like you're about to tear out your hair before suddenly having an epiphany and feeling like an absolute genius.  I like that a lot and it adds an incredibly surprising level of depth to what some might assume would just be the same thing over and over again.

If you're looking for something fast paced with lots of action, this really isn't for you.  This game requires insane amounts of patience and persistence, getting stuck is painful but once you get your breakthrough it feels fantastic.

reviewText:
The main point of this game is solving insanely challenging puzzles. Sure, there's the exploration of the gorgeous island, but the ultimate goal of THAT is to find puzzles, and solve them, period. Before you know it, you'll be looking everywhere for puzzles. EVERYWHERE. That is the drive of this game.

And yes, puzzles do get VERY hard, very quick. The good news is that you can keep exploring and finding new puzzles to solve. You will feel ecstatic when you finally find a solution, and you also feel very frustrated when you don't. It's not for everyone, but if it sounds like a thing you'd like, I say go for it.

And there's a LOT of puzzles to solve. Like, more than you can imagine there would be. And then some. There's also a sense of mystery and discovery to it all. But, the biggest reward will always be, you guessed it, solving puzzles.

tl;dr PUZZLES!

reviewText:
Luckily, I really like line-drawing puzzles.

6 hr update: I really, really like them.

40 hour update: this game isn't about line-drawing puzzles at all. Drawing lines is just the interface, the language, which the player uses to interact with the game. The puzzles themselves are vast and varied, it just so happens that you speak in Snake to answer them. Even at this point I am discovering new stuff and starting to appreciate the weightier themes of the game as I peel back the onion skin a layer further. I'm not even dismissing the audio logs as pretentious nonsense anymore. It really does all fit together. Just to give one little magic moment without spoiling anything too much. There is a statue you find of a man who is raising his hands to the sky and looks as though he is despairing. Viewed from a slightly different angle, however, his shadow aligns with stones on the ground and suddenly he looks like a guy juggling. And that's the game in a nutshell. It's a masterpiece, one of the very best if not THE best game I have ever played. Thank you Mr. Blow.

reviewText:
The Witness is a fantastic puzzle game with a beautiful world to explore. While the only puzzle mechanic is, more or less, about connecting lines and dots, it does this in a wide variety of ways, from special rules, mirroring lines, and more. After the first couple dozen puzzles, the environment begins to have an effect on them, whether by being part of the puzzle itself from shadows, or from outside objects changing how a puzzle needs to be solved, or preventing it from being solved until later.

The game has its flaws, though. There is no story to guide you, no outright given reason why you are here. This is a detriment to some folks, which I can understand. There are little hints, bits of audio, other things you can find, and there is apparently an underlying story and reason if you dig deep enough. But, as I said, without it being presented up front, that may or may not be an issue to you.

The negative reaction of It's only line puzzles stuck on panels!" is

reviewText:
The Witness is a fantastic puzzle game with a beautiful world to explore. While the only puzzle mechanic is, more or less, about connecting lines and dots, it does this in a wide variety of ways, from special rules, mirroring lines, and more. After the first couple dozen puzzles, the environment begins to have an effect on them, whether by being part of the puzzle itself from shadows, or from outside objects changing how a puzzle needs to be solved, or preventing it from being solved until later.

The game has its flaws, though. There is no story to guide you, no outright given reason why you are here. This is a detriment to some folks, which I can understand. There are little hints, bits of audio, other things you can find, and there is apparently an underlying story and reason if you dig deep enough. But, as I said, without it being presented up front, that may or may not be an issue to you.

The negative reaction of It's only line puzzles stuck on panels!" is
hoursPlayed: it's only line puzzles
voteText: but they get complex and interesting
helpfulPercent: and keep ramping that up with new rules the more puzzles you find. And its hard not to spoil things
votesHelpful: but I will say that there are puzzles outside of thense 'panels'.\n\nAnother negative is this game does not hold your hand. It does not explain how a puzzle mechanic works outside of a set of 'tutorial' panels for each one
votesTotal: which are scattered around with the other puzzle panels. You may be able to discern what the rules are for a certain puzzle piece
votesFunny: though. Sometimes you might not know if a puzzle is actually solvable without changing the environment somehow via a different puzzle. These can make it frustrating
commentsCount: but a good solution is if you can't solve a puzzle after a bit
column16: move on for now and come back.\n\nThe last issue is something I see a bunch of negative reviews and comments on here and elsewhere : That people were expecting Myst becuase thats what it kind of looked like
column17: but didn't get Myst. That's a fairly big aspiration for a game
column18: but don't pass off on a game because it wasn't what you were expecting it to be.\n\nSo
column19:
summing it up :

PROS : Lots of puzzles. Beautiful world. Interesting mechanics.
CONS : Puzzles based off the same Line type. Very little story drive. Limited graphics options."

reviewText:
A Dark Souls of puzzle games"

--------------------------------
* Is this game similar to Myst?
--------------------------------

If you like Myst
date: or Myst-like games with emphasis on exploration
recommended:
you should stop right now and buy it immediately.
This is distilled spiritual successor of Myst and I waited for a game like this for years.

--------------------------------
* Would I like it if i like Talos Principle (Portal
hoursPlayed:
etc)?
--------------------------------

I found people who like Talos giving a lot of negative reviews for reasons not completely clear to me. Those games are on the same level in terms of difficulty and complexity
voteText: but the core philosophy behind the games is completely different.\n\nTalos is more of a Portal-like puzzle game where the mechanic of the puzzle is simple
helpfulPercent:
but the solution can be incredibly complex.

Witness has more of the Myst like approach. The puzzle machanic is usually hidden and your goal is to discover it. Essentially it depends on if you like this kind of games.


--------------------------------
* I am afraid this is another indie crap with bad puzzles
--------------------------------

* This is easily an AAA tile.

This is not an indie game
votesHelpful: well
votesTotal: not your regular indie game. It was not made by a single person
votesFunny: and even if it was
commentsCount: this is not what automatically should make it a low budget indie.\nThe production quality of this game is insane. Speaking in a Myst terms
column16:
I would say I found it easily on a pair with Raven or Exile.

* This is not an 'only maze puzzles' game.

There is a lot of misunderstanding about this part and trailer not really explainging it well.
What I was expected initially from the Witness is a collection of small mini-games where you just need to go through the maze. This did not sound really exciting to be honest.
Every time dev is asked "are there only maze puzzles" the answer is always "yes
column17: there are only maze puzzles" and I wonder why did he not take time to explain this
column18:
because this statement is incorrect.

* Panels are not puzzles.

Panels are not puzzles
column19: but rather interactive interfaces in the game. They work on the similar principle
column20: but do a lot of different stuff.\nThey activate and deactivate different machinery
column21: open doors and move elevators
column22: they modify game environment
column23:
etc.
Think of them as unorthodox touchscreens or gearboxes.

* Puzzles are not mazes.

Let's be honest: the variety of the puzzles in the game is insane. There are logic puzzles
column24: but there are also optical puzzles based on the effects light and shadow or color mixture
column25: there are sound puzzles
column26: mechanical and kinetic puzzles
column27:
puzzles based on the environment and so on.
There are typically three group of puzzles:

* One is some sort of tutorial
column28:
where you learn the rules of the game in a seris of progressively more complex tasks.

* Then there are puzzles that combine several rules at the same time.
(They may be really confusign at fist
column29:
but it usually means that you don't have enough information or understanding of the game at this moment).

* And finally there is a metagame level where you suddenly discover that established rules may work outside of their usual context if you start to think outside the box.

Almost all of the game elements are interconnected in some way
column30: and the main goal of the game is to find those connections.\n(Which is
column31: needless to say
column32:
insanely addictive and fun)

reviewText:
This game (much like Fez) forces your brain to flip from one thought process to another in a heartbeat.  In short, it's another piece of genius from J-Blo.  It makes me feel like my brain is being ravaged by a bigger brain, whilst dangling an obvious answer right in front of my semi-ravaged brain face.

If you learn to think outside the box and look at the environment - you'll get to grips with this pretty fast.  If you only work on the puzzle that's in front of you... you're boned.

12 out of 10. Would definitely get brain-ravaged again.
voteText: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I really, really wanted to enjoy this game. I've been anticipating its release since I first heard about it and I even preordered the game.

Simply put, I did not find the game enjoyable. There's probably depth to it that I didn't understand in my 30 mintues of play time, but I just got exceptionally bored playing the game. It feels like puzzles you'd find in a cheap mobile app, but this game costs $40. I might pick it up whenever it hits $5 in a sale but I just can't justify full price.

The world is very beautiful, however I couldn't find anything interactive about it. The world just seems to link together all of the mobile phone game puzzles. You also are very limited in movement: you can't jump or drop small ledges. This is an annoyance.
voteText: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Incredible amount of things to do and discover. I played 13 hours the day it released, and I still feel like the end isn't really in sight. And that's not to say that the puzzles get repetitive and mundane. On the contrary, the more I play, the more I am able to understand and engage with the more difficult puzzles, some of which are truly brilliant in design.\n\nHowever, be aware that MUCH of what you do in this game will be drawing lines in a grid interface. However, so much discovery and exploration happens outside of that interface, and much of that discovery unveils new puzzle mechanics, which let you progress further into the vast and mysterious island in The Witness. This game absolutely might not be for you if you can't get over the puzzle input mechanism. But if you want to be dropped in a world with endless places and puzzles to discover and solve, The Witness is the game for you.

reviewText: The Witness is a beguiling game of deceptive simplicity. You'll see a lot of criticism aimed at it from people who have only scratched the surface of the game distiling the game down to just tracing line puzzles". While it is true a large selection of the game are maze-like puzzles where you attempt to trace one unbroken line to the end without overlapping itself
date: the variations on this are vast and fascinating. Whie traversing this beautifully constructed digital island you unravel the various ruleset of these puzzles with non-verbal communication. This game has a lot more in common with the Cyan Worlds games (Myst
hoursPlayed: etc.) but instead of pushing an archaic
voteText: aging button to activate a portion of a puzzle like in Myst
helpfulPercent: The Witness unifies all contraptions into a unified puzzle language which serves to thematically tie all puzzles together.\n\nBut the true beauty is in the story and narrative provided. You have to work hard in order to piece together the "story" of this place you find yourself in
votesHelpful: but its a grand combination of philosophies from a myriad of schools of thought presented in a way that only video/computer games can provide. The story being told in The Witness isn't one of sci-fi mysticism
votesTotal: but instead the story presented wants you to meet it more than halfway. It wants to hear your own ideas and preceptions as much as it wants to present its own.\n\nThis is also a hard game to talk about without giving away a lot of what makes it so special
votesFunny: and that discovery is a large part of its genius. So $39.99 is really a cheap ticket of entry for an experience that is priceless
commentsCount: but I also realize that the experience isn't for everyone but it was definitely an experience I enjoyed thoroughly."

voteText: mindblowing. Thank you Jonathan for an extraordinary experience! 40 bucks well spent."

reviewText:
The Witness is wonderful, meaning full of wonder, and awesome, meaning it elicits awe.

I think this game could inspire a love for learning in a child.

I'm only probably a tenth or so in to the game, but I've already gotten my money's worth. The island is opening up in layers of meaning, layers of understanding. The whole island is a series of allegories layered atop one another and beckoning the curious explorer.

Blow's design objective -- to model epiphany -- requires inductive reasoning of the player. This game is entirely inductive reasoning. It's the most dense use of this rare mechanic that I've ever seen presented in a game.

I heartily recommend this game as an excellent use of your time.

reviewText:
Overall this is a fantastic game, with a beatiful art style and immersive atmosphere.

WARNING FOR HARD OF HEARING/DEAF, COLOR BLIND, AND EPILEPTIC PEOPLE:
This game features puzzles which require hearing specific sounds in a noisy environment, separating and grouping colors, and separating and grouping colors on a strobing background.  Some of these are required for completion of the game.

+Intricate puzzles that I really have to think to solve, and remain fresh and challenging throughout the game.
+Beautiful visuals, with strategically placed ledges to look over the island from
+Incorporates the world into the maze style puzzles often and in various ways
+Well presented tutorial for each kind of puzzle, without ever actually explaining how to solve them
+Hidden puzzle paths in the environment, requiring proper perspective to find and activate.
-No idea what these are for

-Slow machinery.  It build the atmosphere, but I would rather make progress than wait for an elevator.
-Almost too difficult.  There are no difficulty options, if you can't finish you can't finish.
-Hidden puzzle paths in the environment are very obscure and difficult to find.  Getting 100% is nearly impossible.

reviewText: This is one of the best puzzle games I've ever played. It is not an adventure puzzler, it is a pure puzzle game - and it pulls that off perfectly.\nPeople complain you only draw lines on squares"
date: but that's like saying "you only shoot portals on walls" (Portal/Portal 2) or "you only hit a ball into a hole" (Golf)
recommended: or "you only shoot enemies." (Every FPS in existence). The puzzles evolve using the same basic mechanic. Without words or instructions it guides you through every nuance of each mechanic.\nThe feeling of a puzzle clicking in your mind after being stuck in this game is one of the best feelings a game has ever given me. I found myself smiling in pride after many puzzles.\nUnderstand what this game is and isn't before you buy it. But understand that it's one of the best pure puzzle experiences I've ever had the pleasure of playing."

reviewText: The Witness is my current favorite game, and I want to tell everyone all about it. The only problem is, if I tell people about what makes it so great, it will ruin the best part about the game, which is experiencing it for one's self. Its one of those games that I wish I could go back and experience it again for the first time. Its definitely not for everyone, and that's fine. If you don't like semi-difficult puzzles, you probably won't like this game, but I encourage everyone to give it a try I also recommend that you go in blind, which I understand the irony of including in a review of the game. I've done everything there is to do in the game, as far as I know, but I wouldn't be surprised if there were a few deep secrets that I missed, that will eventually be unearthed by those with more free time than myself. More secrets or not, I have absolutely enjoyed every bit of The Witness, and am completely satisfied with my experience.

reviewText: This is this generation's Myst. It's a beautiful, imaginative, & cognitively demanding puzzle/exploration experience. The central theme is totally in your face, yet never overtly dictated. It's one of the most rewarding experiences I've had playing games to date. Get it, struggle thru it, then go back and watch YouTube videos of other people playing it, & marvel at the power of knowledge.

reviewText:
This is truly the best puzzle game I've played so far,
and this is coming from someone who has played hundreds before.

Of course, if you absolutely hate puzzle games, this may not be for you,
but if you've ever enjoyed games such as Portal, The Room, Talos Principle,
Braid, Myst, etc, this game is the pinnacle of puzzle games.

The preview is purposefully vague, and if you look for videos online,
what you will find will look fairly repetitive and dull, but this game is so far from that.
At no point it feels like a grind or a chore like many other puzzle games do.

In this game, each puzzle brings something new, each puzzle makes you feel smart.
But not artificially, the game is all about letting you have real epiphanies.
It never hand holds you, you have to do all the work, and that's why it's satisfying.

This game, unlike many other puzzle games, isn't about solving a puzzle given a clear
set of rules, but rather about figure out the rules yourself. It first teaches you a simple
puzzle language"
recommended: it runs wild and you have to follow on your own.\n\nThe main gameplay aside
hoursPlayed: the gorgeous scenes is probably what you first notice looking\nat all the media and trailers. It definitely helps the experience
voteText:
and is refreshing to look at
between solving puzzles. There are also hidden audiologs throughout the world (with
amazing voice acting) which again can be soothing inbetween puzzles.

The one big complaint I do have about the game is slow animations. Anything
that movies is painfully slow
helpfulPercent: and I'm guessing it is to get you to enjoy the scenery
votesHelpful:
but I think that's bad game design.

All in all
votesTotal: I truly think this game is a work of art which will remembered years\nin the future. It does so many things right and brings a lot to the genre."

reviewText:
Spoilers: I have 100% completed this game.  Then I went to bed.  When I woke up I found myself asking a few questions about it.

First, did I enjoy the experience while playing it?  Yes.  I enjoy a good puzzle and this game offered plenty of them.  They varied in difficulty and strategy and combined in interesting and creative ways.  I relished the Ah-Ha" moments of finally solving a puzzle that had been stumping you for 10 minutes.  It was a well realized and truly enjoyable experience.

Second
date: would I play this game again?  No.  The primary issue of this game is that once it is learned then no challenge remains.  This is hardly a unique criticism of a puzzle game as the same can be said of Myst and it is still held up as a classic
recommended: but it does degrade the overall joy the game can bring me.  I have found that the best games are ones that can be played over and over for years bringing something new each time.  Unfortunately this game can not offer that.\n\nThird
hoursPlayed: what did it all mean?  On this I am unsure.  If we are to take it at face value as a puzzle game then it holds up well for the reasons given above.  This does however raise an issue.  If the game is really about just solving puzzles then the only plot and story we are given is philosophical readings then why bother to include it those readings at all?  The Witness quickly teaches you that nothing is arbitrary.  If something is shaped in a strange or odd way
voteText: then it is a puzzle.  The game
helpfulPercent: from the onset
votesHelpful: demonstrates that it is not haphazardly constructed and that all of the minute things that are included are deeply necessary for some reason that may not yet be clear.  It shows you that if you just dig deeper you can find the answer; you can solve the puzzle.  From this core concept of the game we must conclude that the philosophical readings have a function
votesTotal: a purpose
votesFunny: in the larger game.  Unfortunately
commentsCount: that is the flaw in this experience.  No plot resolution is given.  (Yes even with both endings.)  Saying "It was all a dream
column16: or a simulation" doesn't inform the philosophy discussed.  It doesn't illuminate the goals or purpose of the people whose voices we have heard.  Who are they?  What are they doing?  Why should we care?  The game spends its entire span showing you that answers will come to those persistent and clever enough to find them.  Then it changes the rules with 10 seconds left on the clock and unfortunately declares: None of that Matters.  It wasn't real.  This is a critical mishandling of an otherwise perfect setup.  I can and have thought of literally 10 better endings since I started writing this.  Sadly this game falls woefully short in that respect.\n\nWith that said
column17: perhaps overly harshly
column18: I still did truly enjoy the game as I played it and I will recommend it to friends.  Unfortunately
column19: I will be recommending it as a puzzle solving game.  Just a puzzle solving game.  This had the potential to be so much more.  There is perhaps nothing so tragic as a wasted opportunity."

reviewText: If you like puzzles, this is your game, end of story. If not, it's not your game. I am surprised by some of the negative remarks.\n\nPeople say there's too much of the same puzzle. Well, you bought a puzzle game, so that's astute of you to notice. And if you think the puzzles never change, then you quit after 5 minutes. There is only one type of puzzle, but it's a deliberate choice. This game uses one basic method of interaction - find a path through a maze - and layers different rulesets on top of it. Some of the later puzzles are nothing short of meta, where your solution will end up represented in the real world
date: or you will have to solve mazes on top of each other. Really, the game takes one idea and does it perfect, taking it as far as it can go. I personally dislike when games try to have variety" but only end up doing 5
recommended: 000 thing mediocre. If you want something else
hoursPlayed: buy something else and quit whining.\n\nPeople also say it's pretentious. Well
voteText: it's Jonathan Blow. What did you expect? I honestly didn't find the game itself pretentious
helpfulPercent: but the audio logs and videos you find throughout the game certainly are. But hey
votesHelpful: you don't *have* to watch/listen to any of them
votesTotal: so if you dislike that kind of thing
votesFunny: no harm
commentsCount: no foul.\n\nPeople also say the ending is terrible. Well
column16: there's no way to say this without spoilers... but you didn't actually find the ending!\n\nPeople also say it's too much money. I sympathize with that because $40 is sometimes a person's entire games budget for a month
column17: or season
column18: or even year. Just wait until it goes on sale. Whatever you do
column19: DON'T pirate it. Don't be that guy. You think you're sending the message to Jonathan Blow that he needs to reduce the price
column20: but the real message you send (and the one he got) is that he should put DRM on his next game. Don't. Just wait until a sale. I think it is worth the $40
column21: though
column22:
so if you are able to spend that kind of cash and you like puzzle games you have no excuse.

People also say it has no replay value. This makes sense because I never played Myst or Riven again after I beat them once. Oh wait that was sarcasm.

Just buy the damn thing"

reviewText: This game is Oh. My. God. good. Without spoiling anything, it drops you on an island without telling you what you have to do. But it teaches you what you have to do. The pace at which the game grows is very linear. You're super lost at first, but the game teaches you what to do with this confusion which is awesome. Also, there's a meta part to the game that blew my mind when I found it, and if you play a second time through, you find things you never can't even access in the first playthrough. 10/10 Very fun, very well made, makes you think about a lot of cool stuff.

reviewText: I have played this in excess of 80 hours if you combine what I played on the Playstation 4 and without a doubt I can say that I will recommend this game fully if you want a great puzzle game. Visuals are stunning if you have the capibilty to run it at the highest graphics settings. Music although mostly non-existant is actually a plus in this game & the sounds of the game is amazing.   The lack of traditional tutorials are actually a bouns.   I hope everyone takes the opertunity to buy this game & support a great development team.

reviewText:
This might be the most polarizing game experience of my life...

On one hand, The Witness is both beautiful and brilliant from an artistic and design sense. The lighting, materials and rendering are pure eye candy. The entire island integrates perfectly to form a continuous chain of incredibly intelligent puzzles.

On the other hand, The Witness is also one of the most boring, poorly paced and non sensical games I have ever played. The story is told through audio logs which have no consitant theme and are mostly told out of context. While the rendering is great, the envirronment itself is bland comprised mostly of generic trees, rocks, cave walls, brick walls, wood planks, etc. Almost nothing has character in this world. The vast majority of the puzzles consist of standing in front of a grid and drawing lines to separate different icons. This gets very old and repetitive.

Regardless of the low entertainment value, I have to reccomend this game beacuse it is just too inteligently designed to pass up. There are a lot of great ideas here.  Everyone should witness at least the first few hours of brilliance before the repetitive bordem sets in.

reviewText:
Definitely not a game for everyone:
If you want something relaxing (unless you consider mental exercises as relaxing), this isn't it.
It you want something that doesn't remind you of math blaster, this isn't it.
If you want something with puzzles where you don't need to draw on paper or take screenshots, this isn't it.
If you want to feel like your not working or in school, this isn't it.

I'm not sure who would have the drive needed to work on a game like this one for seven years, but it was done. The love for these maze puzzles needs to be extensive for a player to ever complete this thing.

I'm not sure I'd ever complete it even if paid to do so as I don't like those puzzle anywhere near that much.

There's a reviewer out there that said maze puzzles for 25-30+ hours should be what you should consider to play this game. That's no joke. Take it seriously. If your not sure, its likely not for you. I wasn't sure and its totally not for me.

Addition: The Myst series even with its flaws and taking the worst one, are still better. Some of the puzzles are similar, such as the one in the fireplace, but many are more relaxing and more entertaining, and the puzzles are far more varied. The Witness is just interesting. Its solve the maze puzzle to see what's next or walk over there to see what's next. Myst also has a nice story and doesn't feel completely lonely.

This game also has invisible walls which for first person game that's no good. You can't fall off anything when you want to.

There's no jumping so forget that.

Its all about the maze puzzles and roaming for a good amount of time. That's what you do. You better like it.

They do a good job of making the maze puzzles more interesting with the sound effect and the look. It helps make them less dull, but that's it.

reviewText:
It's pretty. It's like Myst. If you liked Myst, you will probably like this. Some of the puzzles are fun, but what were the devs thinking, making you go back and re-solve puzzles you've already solved? I cannot fathom what was going through their heads.

So, for example you have to solve a maze, draw a path through this grid so it covers all of these dots and none of those dots. Okay, good, you do that, find the solution, and then you move on to the next one, which is the same idea but harder this time. The problem is, if you fail the hard one, you then have to GO BACK to the one you just solved, erase your solution, and enter the exact same solution again. Every time. Every single time you need to retry the hard puzzle, you have to go back and erase and re-solve the one you already finished.

What in the world could have possessed them to put such a tedious and boring mechanic in a puzzle game? It's like being forced to erase all your answers from a crossword puzzle and then write them in again, exactly the same. Over and over. Who would want to do that!?

Meh. The puzzles are fine, although some of them seem to be a bit less solve this logic problem" and more "guess what I'm thinking of"
date: since I'm faily sure I found working solutions to a few puzzles only to have the game reject them because a different solution was expected. So then you get to go back and try to find another solution
recommended: even though you already found a perfectly good one. Maybe there was some reason why the solution that eventually worked was better than the one I initially came up with
hoursPlayed: but if so I can't work it out.\n\nAnyway. The world looks good. It would be great if it supported VR--which it doesn't. Having to go back and fill out puzzles you've already completed is a boring waste of time. If that sounds like something you're okay with

reviewText:
This game is not going to be for everyone. If you're looking for a game that has action, violence, and an engaging plot that will keep you on the edge of your seat, look elsewhere. If you're impatient, and if you don't want your brain to hurt, this isn't the game for you. With that being said, in the amount of time I've invested in The Witness so far, it's already one of my favorite puzzle games of all time. The game takes the basic concept of maze puzzles, and introduces new mechanics to them to make you think. It then takes those new mechanics, and gives them a little twist, to make you think even more. And then once you think you've mastered that mechanic, it mixes it with another mechanic that you've previously learned, or even a brand new one. This game is hard, and it doesn't make any attempt to hold your hand. This game is going to make you want to smash your head onto your desk, but in a good way, because you want to conquer this latest puzzle so badly.

The game has an incredible atmosphere, with gorgeous visuals and ambient sounds immersing you into this island world. There aren't any graphics settings, which is a huge bummer, but hopefully that is something that could be patched into the game. The vibrant colors of the island really pop off the screen, and the different locations throughout the game are really neat. You can also listen to some audio diaries located throughout the island, which have different quotes from all sorts of different people. This would be a great game to have a podcast on in the background. Not that the sounds are bad, they do a good enough job to keep you immersed in the game while you're playing, but it might be nice to have something else to listen to as well. The controls work great, on both a controller and a keyboard and mouse. Pick whichever one you're more comfortable with. I know a lot of people have been complaining about the $40 price tag, but from what I've played so far, it seems absolutely worth it. There are a ton of puzzles in here, and it's going to take you awhile to beat the game.

tl;dr I you want something different than a complex puzzle game that keeps you on your toes with a great atmosphere, you're going to want to look elsewhere. But if you've been craving a game like The Talos Principle or Portal, you should absolutely pick this up. This game is worth the price tag, and it's going to be a long time before you forget your time in The Witness.

reviewText:
As a fan of puzzle games, I find it hard to recommend The Witness.

The price point is very steep, the storyline is very barebones and pretentious, the (normal) ending is a royal kick in the balls, and the rules to new puzzles are often poorly represented. There are even some solutions that require you to take screenshots and solve them outside of the game. I'm not sure about everyone, but I prefer to have all the tools to solve a game within the game itself. I'm not a fan of solutions that break immersion.

It's a shame because I would consider myself a fan of Jonathan Blow. Even with the game's faults, the environment is gorgeous with thought provoking set peices. Despite everything feeling 'dead' and 'sterile', there is a persistent sense of mystery that makes you want to explore all that the world has to offer. Every zone has a theme, every theme has a new rule, and every new rule causes you to think differently.

On paper, this sounds like a lot of fun, and I would be lying if I said I didn't have fun, but in practice this game is designed to be solved very slowly with every zone containing several mental road blocks. While I'm all for challenge in video games, it should not come at the cost of proper pacing. There are quite a few puzzles to solve and though some are genuinely clever, most involve contorting the camera to the 'exact' angle required to complete a path, look at the environment a certain way, see through a specific window, look at just the right reflection, and so on. It gets to be more awkward than enjoyable.

If you're a fan of puzzle/artsy games, I would pick this up for a 1/4 of its current price. Everyone else: Avoid.

reviewText:
An excellent puzzler for those with an open mind, and a wonderful example of good design. can't figure out a puzzle? take a walk around the island, eventually you will find what you need. this game heavily rewards observation, and even though i have yet to finish it, I can't help but reccomend it.

The story itself, too, is arguably a puzzle, as rather than be explained to you it must be inferred from your surroundings. a statue here, some tech there, and you begin to get a glimpse of what the hell happened to the people on the island. it isn't straight forward, but rather more of a silent, postapocalyptic log.

over all, if you aren't convinced, wait to grab it on sale. this is one of those games that you won't enjoy if you don't go in with an open mind- and i mean very open. if you're the type to get frustrated and give up, or need positive re-enforcement, this probably isn't the game for you; this is a bad analogy, but i'd almost consider this the dark souls equivalent of a puzzle game.

10/10 would have an epiphany on how i need to split a puzzle in half on the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ again.

reviewText:
Possible spoilers.  This is an exploration/puzzle game.  Knowing literally anything about the way it plays could be considered a spoiler.  If this describes how you feel about such games, read with caution.

I haven't beaten it yet.  Don't know if I care to.  I'm not sure a game has made me legitimately angry at its creator before.

I absolutely loved Braid.  Very clever game, premise, puzzles.  A satisfying sort of headscratcher.  I'll admit I had to look up how to get (or mainly, where to find) a few of the stars.

This...just...hum.  I liked it at first.  It has worn me down and made me regret my rare early-adoption.  Knowing what I know now, I would not have chosen to give Jon Blow $40 for it.  Sadly I have more than two hours of patience.

Good:
- Very many puzzles
- A pretty game, with an artistic style and varying biomes and color palettes
- A fair amount of cleverness in the way many of the puzzles (and their rules) are implemented

Bad:
- Inconsistent design; the game feels like it is designed well in some ways and intentionally poorly in others
- Default movement speed is pretty slow (running should be a toggle, not a hold)
- Voice recorders hidden throughout the island, as well as difficult-to-solve optional puzzles, 'reward' you with philosophical preaching and quotes which feel shoehorned-in and fake-deep, rather than thought-provoking

In the areas you are likely to interact with the earliest, the experience is the smoothest.  There are sets of panels throughout the game that are clearly intended to teach you a puzzle mechanic (without explicitly telling you what it is).  The earlier-introduced mechanics or puzzle rules are, I would say, inherently easier to grasp in an intuitive manner.  The ones you find later (further from the starting point, generally speaking - village puzzles a notable exception) are much less obvious.  This is all fine on its own.  These various rules leave a lot of room for interpretation, to where your understanding of them is gradually refined based on how you solved this one, but later tried to solve another one with the same line of thinking and it just didn't work.  In many cases it amounts to I just was looking at it the wrong way
date: in a figurative and/or literal sense.  That is a consistent theme throughout this game: perception.  In the beginning, it seems brilliant.\n\nThe game's design philosophy of just look at it from a different angle" begins to work against it as you proceed in the game.  For some puzzles
recommended: the precise literal angle from which you have to look can be so obscure that I think some players may have no recourse but to look up the solution or simply never solve it.  Looking up the solution obviously ruins the whole premise and takes the fun out of it
hoursPlayed: but there have been times where I left a puzzle
voteText: came back to it
helpfulPercent: left it again
votesHelpful: came back again
votesTotal: and finally had to conclude that I just was not going to see how to do it on my own.  I've seen the words "frustration tolerance" in at least one review of this game
votesFunny: and I've come to find that it has greatly reduced mine.\n\nThen there are design decisions that just do not make sense to me
commentsCount: especially given that you can tell they are conscious
column16: intentional design decisions and not something they might explain as "that's just the way we did it."  For example
column17: the default movement speed is an irritatingly slow walk.  I'm tired of holding down the shift key.  Another weird decision will become apparent at some point when you fail a puzzle in a series - a "series" being when a number of puzzles are either all lined up next to each other
column18: or simply linked by wires that glow and activate the next puzzle panel (also helpfully leading you to it).  For reasons I cannot fathom
column19: some of these puzzles will deactivate when you input an incorrect solution.  To reactivate the puzzle
column20: you have to go back to the previous panel (wherever it is) and re-input the correct solution
column21: which will still be lit up on the panel for you.  Then you can go back (again) to the one you just failed
column22: and try another solution (and be prepared to walk back to the previous panel again
column23: if you are on the wrong track).  For a game whose creator claims he wants to "trust in the intelligence of the player
column24:
I'm feeling a disturbing lack of respect for the time I'm putting into it.  While I walk back and forth between panels repeatedly, arbitrarily wasting time in penance for having the audacity to suggest -that- was the solution, I imagine I could be doing something fun.

Finally, there is a distinct effort to establish, early on, clear methods of game-to-player communication.  The glowing wires from puzzle to puzzle.  The short series of easy puzzles to introduce you to a concept.  The fact that you can activate literally anything that looks like a circle with a line coming away from it.  These are all solid design choices that create a feeling of consistency.  And then, there are arbitrary decisions that erode that consistency and my confidence that I've made the correct choice in how to spend my time.  Sometimes you can finish a puzzle and follow the wire to what should be the next one, only to see it leading into some crevice, maybe coming out somewhere else that simply cannot be found.  However, these are not cases of well you just didn't look hard enough." I walked around the whole area multiple times and finally googled it to find that there just isn't another puzzle in that series.  Then why is there a wire leading away from the last one?  What does it do?   Why should I trust anything the game communicates now?  Reminds me of how convinced I was to buy this based solely on how good Braid was.

The "story" appears to consist of what you can find in hidden-to-sort-of-hidden voice recorders.  Most of which (of the ones I've found) seem to consist of Einstein quotes.  I don't really care about that
column25: it's not a story.  It's not what I care to hear
column26: so I just stopped clicking on them.  It doesn't feel like a mystery
column27: it feels like someone trying to convince you of how smart they are.  I wasn't exactly expecting a blockbuster story or anything
column28: but it gives the whole thing an extra layer of pretentiousness and makes me even less interested in whatever the "ending" consists of.  If I'm missing out on actual story because of this
column29: I can't help but point to the design decision of "put pretentious science-vs.-religion quotes in voice recorders" as the cause.  I might have been more receptive to that kind of message if I found something actually written for this game first.\n\nI now feel like I am having a conversation with Jonathan Blow if I play this game
column30: where I might say
column31: "I liked that stuff over there
column32: but not this part.  Why is it like this?  It doesn't make sense."  And he might say
column33: "Well
column34: it doesn't have to make sense
column35: and we don't have to agree.  You're obviously doing it wrong.  I'm not holding your hand.  Go put in that other puzzle solution again if you want to keep bashing your head on this."\n\nI can (and may) just stop playing it out of spite
column36: but he's already got my money either way."

reviewText:
Buy it only if you are super-super nerd who loves abstract puzzles above anything else.

Beware of possible bad experience from the game.

Review:

The beginning of a game has too many repetitive puzzles. I was forcing myself through the beginning and the middle of it. Sometimes I felt frustration because of seldom rewards from puzzles. Too many of easy puzzles there and that felt like a drudge-work. Where is all the fun? The worst experience was when I solved couple of puzzles and nothing just happened. What was the point?

The end-game puzzles were really good and they gave me a feeling of hand crafted experience. But I am sure that not many of you will get to the end-game to enjoy it. End-game puzzles cannot compensate for the overall boring process of the game.

The game has ended too-indie-like (read it as no real ending at all). This game lacks the story, in fact it lacks almost everything except nice views here and there and puzzles. Sad face.

The whole island feels like a crazy big tutorial with too stretched learning experience of too many puzzles. The end-game felt like the game finally has started, but it was not long enough to compensate for boring exploration experience of the island.

But again. No mystery gets uncovered in the game. There is no plot, no story, no nothing to think about afterwards. Random philospohy felt like a sand into my eye. Too cheap, sorry.

Compared to Braid it is:
a) a step back as a game
b) a step forward in nerdiness of puzzles.

reviewText: I love puzzle games, and count Myst, Portal and The Talos Principle among my favorite ever, but I just can't stand the puzzles in The Witness. I find them boring, tedious, and pretentiously difficult. Anyone can make difficult puzzles by working backwards from the solution, and obfuscating the steps, but it takes real design prowess to make puzzles that are fun and rewarding to solve. The Witness just mocks you constantly, and dares you to think you have a brain. I got to a point where I solved a puzzle, then it gave me the exact same puzzle again, but with the paths broken so I had to find another solution. It really just felt like a big middle finger. And I just don't want to have to sit through any more of the videos and sound bites. As soon as I had the thought, maybe I should just use a walk through to solve all the annoying puzzles so I can see what there is to the rest of this game" then I knew it was over for me. I have zero desire to play any more. It's sad
date: because it's a really beautiful game and really has a Myst vibe. I don't know how far I am in the game

reviewText:
Almost certainly the best puzzle game ever made!

First, a caveat: I'm a little miffed (as others have pointed out) that the world isn't as interactive as we'd believed. At its core, the game is, in fact, a series of puzzles, albeit with plenty of twists and turns along the way. (Some of the puzzles point to a much more interesting interaction model for the second half of the game, but we'll see how that goes.) Personally, I would have preferred more explicit adventure game elements, especially since the game never eases up on you. It feels like the Kreedz Climbing of puzzles!

Still -- the island is GORGEOUS, the (micro-)story is intriguing, and the feeling of progress is quite intoxicating. (There's even a bit of humor! Who knew that abstract line puzzles could be funny?) Aside from being a marvel of game design -- everything is taught through the puzzles -- this is clearly a very personal work for its creator. I've put in 10 hours so far and I'm still as engaged as when I first started.

Highly recommended!

reviewText:
The witness is a puzzle game, with mild elements of exploration. Having come into this game expecting akin to Braid I was sorely disappointed. I am dissapointed, not because this game doesn't have puzzles or atmosphere, but because its a very isolating game. While figuring out the puzzles there is no background music, no overarching narrative - just the complusion to better your puzzle solving skills.

Don't get me wrong, the puzzles in this game are great. The build up of the puzzle design is great. The art design is great - but it feels hollow overall. I guess I could liken this game to someone making a rubiks cube simulator with hundreds of different rubiks cubes. Is there hours of game play here - yeah - is it misleading in its purpose - no. Would I play it for hours on end - no.

In regards to the puzzles specifically, as mentioned previously I feel like they are well done, but at the same time some of them start to feel gimmicky. I can't think of a good example of this, but I feel like puzzles should be self-contained, and should not require the environment outside of the puzzle to solve.

Is the witness a good puzzle game? Yes
Is the witness a game that I would recommend? No

reviewText: Of all the games I've downloaded on Steam, The Witness has been the biggest ripoff. It was a huge disappointment. I had read the mixed reviews, but still felt it would be a game I would be interested in. I was wrong. The puzzles are all variations of the exact same puzzle, but there is no real rhyme or reason the the cues that are meant to guide you to a solution for each. All of the puzzles are either absurdly easy or impossibly difficult. It feels like a terrible mobile game. It is a failed attempt at greater meaning. It was as a shallow a game as I've played, and it just plain and simple wasn't fun at all to play.

reviewText: The Witness starts off great. It has beautiful visuals and just leaves you to its devices, which teach you how to play the game without just flat out telling you, making you feel very rewarded when you learn a new mechanic. However, The Witness starts dragging its feet the first few hours. Everything The Witness has to offer is centered around solving geometric puzzles on panels, very few of which are easy, and there's roughly about 50,000,000,000 of them. Maybe the designers didn't want the player lacking for content, or maybe they didn't want to you finish the game so quickly and just take in the world, but they went to the other extreme. There's just too much of it. You'll start to get bored, and progress will too slow coming in the game. Opening a can of soup in the world of The Witness is a 20 puzzle affair and 3 hour ordeal. As this drags on, the beatiful visuals and atmosphere will start to become meaningless, and The Witness will feel like a very large Sudoku book. Fun to play in very short burst when you're bored, but you don't go through the whole book in few sittings like you do a game. If you play this game, I'd have a walkthrough near by, take 30 seconds to solve a puzzle on your own, and if you can get it, look at that walkthrough and move on to the next one. Don't worry about feeling cheated, there's plenty of opportunity to solve puzzles on your own. But there lies the problem with this game. All there is to The Witness is these mountain of puzzles, and by the end of the game, you'll be sick of them and sick of The Witness.
